studio = [[Kennedy Miller Mitchell|Kennedy Miller Productions]] | editing = [[Jay Friedkin]]
[[Margaret Sixel]] | music = [[Nigel Westlake]] | cinematography = [[Andrew Lesnie]] | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1998|11|25|United States|1998|12|10|Australia}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Magda Szubanski]] * [[James Cromwell]] * [[Mickey Rooney]] }} | narrator = [[Roscoe Lee Browne]] | runtime = 96 minutes | country = Australia
United States | language = English | budget = $90 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=babepiginthecity.htm |title=Babe: Pig in the City (1998) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2002-08-28 |access-date=2015-11-13}} | gross = $69.1 million }} '''''Babe: Pig in the City''''' is a 1998 [[comedy-drama]] [[adventure film]]. It is the [[sequel]]/[[epilogue]] to the 1995 film ''[[Babe (film)|Babe]]'' and the second and final chapter of the ''Babe'' film series. It is co-written, produced and directed by [[George Miller (filmmaker)|George Miller]], who co-wrote and produced the original film.{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/812891/Babe-2-Pig-in-the-City/full-credits.html|title=Babe: Pig in the City|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]] ([[Time Warner]])|location=[[Atlanta]]|access-date=9 July 2017}} Most of the actors from the first film reprised their respective roles, including [[James Cromwell]], [[Miriam Margolyes]], [[Hugo Weaving]], Danny Mann, [[Roscoe Lee Browne]] and [[Magda Szubanski]]. [[Glenne Headly]], [[Steven Wright]], [[James Cosmo]], Myles Jeffrey, and [[Mickey Rooney]] also feature. However, most of them have only brief appearances, as the story focuses on the journey of Babe (now voiced by [[E. G. Daily|Elizabeth Daily]] in place of [[Christine Cavanaugh]]). The film was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]] at the [[71st Academy Awards|1998 Academy Awards]]. The film was neither critically [[Box-office bomb|nor commercially as successful]] as its predecessor, grossing only $69.5 million on a $90 million budget{{Cite web|last=Tobias|first=Scott|date=19 March 2018|title=The New Cult Canon: Babe: Pig In The City|url=https://www.avclub.com/the-new-cult-canon-babe-pig-in-the-city-1798213543|url-status=live|website=The A.V. Club|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210630090807/https://www.avclub.com/the-new-cult-canon-babe-pig-in-the-city-1798213543 |archive-date=30 June 2021 }} and receiving mixed reviews. ==Plot== A few weeks after the events of the first film, Arthur Hoggett is injured in an accident while he and Babe attempt to fix the farm's well, leaving his wife Esme to tend the farm alone. Then threatened with eviction at the end of the month unless the mortgage is paid, Esme takes Babe to a sheepdog herding contest in hope of using the prize money to save the farm. At the city of Metropolis' airport, an overzealous sniffer dog falsely signals that Babe and Esme are carrying drugs, causing them to miss their flight and forcing a few days wait for the next flight home. At first unable to find a hotel that allows animals, Esme and Babe find accommodation at a hotel run by Miss Floom, who likes animals. There Babe is separated from Esme and meets a trio of chimpanzees—Bob, his wife Zootie and his little brother Easy—and Thelonius, a civilized Bornean orangutan who is a butler for the landlady's elderly uncle, Fugly. Babe is made part of their clown act, which he is reluctant to appear in until the apes insinuate that he will be paid. Meanwhile, Esme, believing Babe has escaped, goes looking for him but is arrested after an incident involving [[police officers]] and other bystanders while a gang of motorcycles attempted to mug her. The next morning, Fugly is taken to the hospital in a food coma, accompanied by his niece. Left to fend for themselves, the hotel's animal occupants soon become hungry and the chimps decide to steal food from a store, using Babe to distract a pair of guard dogs. Babe rescues one of the dogs when he falls into a canal, who pledges to act as bodyguard to Babe. Having flown all the way to Metropolis, Ferdinand the Duck finds Babe at the hotel, where Zootie gives birth to twins. The celebration is interrupted when several unfriendly [[animal control officer]]s are summoned there by the Flooms' neighbour, Hortense, who dislikes animals. Most of the animals are removed except for Babe, Ferdinand, a capuchin monkey called Tug and a disabled Jack Russell terrier named Flealick. They infiltrate the animal control facility and rescue their wrongfully imprisoned friends. Released from custody, Esme returns to the hotel to find it in disarray and Miss Floom mourning her uncle and the animals capture. After confronting Hortense since she is the one responsible, they track down the animals to a charity dinner and retrieve them all. Floom sells the hotel and gives the proceeds to Esme to save the farm, where she and all the animals go to stay. Esme resumes her duties and Arthur recovers, and after finally fixing the farm's water pump, proudly smiles at Babe and says, "That'll do, Pig. That'll do." ==Cast== * [[Magda Szubanski]] as Esme Cordelia Hoggett, Arthur's wife. * [[Mickey Rooney]] as Fugly Floom, Miss Floom's late uncle. * [[Mary Stein]] as Miss Floom, the hotel's landlady and Fugly's niece. * [[James Cromwell]] as Arthur Hoggett, Esme's husband. * Julie Godfrey as Hortense, the Flooms' neighbor. * Janet Foye and Pamela Hawkins as Miss Hoggett's friends. * [[Paul Livingston]] as a chef at the charity event * Kim Story as the judge{{Cite web |url=http://www.indb.com/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=24 June 2022 |archive-date=30 December 2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051230131807/http://www.indb.com/ |url-status=dead }} * John Upton as a boy at the hospital ===Voices=== * [[E. G. Daily]] as Babe, a [[pig]]. * Danny Mann as Ferdinand, an [[Indian Runner duck]]. ** Mann also voices Tug, the Flooms' Panamanian white-faced capuchin * [[Glenne Headly]] as Zootie, one of the Flooms' chimpanzees who is Bob's wife and Easy's [[Sibling-in-law|sister-in-law]]. * [[Steven Wright]] as Bob, one of the Flooms' chimpanzees who is Zootie's husband and Easy's older brother. * [[James Cosmo]] as Thelonius, a civilized Bornean orangutan who is a servant to Fugly, and later to Arthur and Esme at the end of the film. * [[Nathan Kress]] and Myles Jeffrey as Easy, one of the Flooms' chimpanzees who is Bob's younger brother and Zootie's brother-in-law. * [[Nathan Kress]] as a [[puppy]] that lives on the streets. * [[Stanley Ralph Ross]] as a [[Bull Terrier]] and [[Doberman Pinscher]] guard dog duo. And Bull Terrier become a friend of Babe. * [[Russi Taylor]] as a [[poodle]] that lives on the streets. ** Russi Taylor also voices a choir cat * [[Adam Goldberg (actor)|Adam Goldberg]] as Flealick, a disabled and talkative Jack Russell terrier. * [[Eddie Barth]] as Nigel, a [[Bulldog]] residing in the hotel. ** Eddie Barth also voices Alan, a [[Neapolitan Mastiff]] residing in the hotel. * [[Bill Capizzi]] as Snoop, an overzealous [[beagle]] who works at the airport as a security sniffer. * [[Miriam Margolyes]] as Fly, a [[Border Collie]] who is Rex's wife and Babe's adoptive mother. * [[Hugo Weaving]] as Rex, a Border Collie who is the farm's lead sheepdog, Babe's adoptive father, and Fly's husband. * [[Jim Cummings]] as a [[pelican]] * [[Katie Leigh]] as a [[kitten]] * Evelyn Krape as one of the farm's sheep ** Evelyn Krape also voices some alley cats * Charles Bartlett as a [[cow]] * Michael Edward-Stevens as a [[horse]] *[[Al Mancini]] and Larry Moss as the fish * [[Roscoe Lee Browne]] as the narrator Additional character voices were provided by Lisa Bailey, Balyne Barbosa, [[Victor Brandt]], Jeannie Elias, Pippa Grandison, J. D. Hall, Mark Hammond, Barbara Harris, Wendy Kamenoff, Scott Leavenworthy, Julie Oppenheimer, Deborah Packer, [[Roger Rose]], Carly Schroeder, Joseph Sicari, Aaron Spann, [[Steve Kramer (actor)|Drew Lexi Thomas]], and [[Naomi Watts]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0915208/|title=Naomi Watts|website=IMDb}} ==Production== [[Christine Cavanaugh]], who played Babe in the [[Babe (film)|first film]], was approached to reprise her role, but declined when contract negotiations fell through.{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/christine-cavanaugh-voice-actor-behind-the-eponymous-pig-in-babe-and-the-worrisome-toddler-chuckie-9957883.html | title=Christine Cavanaugh: Voice actor behind the eponymous pig in 'Babe' and the worrisome toddler Chuckie in 'Rugrats' | work=The Independent | date=5 January 2015 | author=Hayward, Anthony}} Cavanaugh was eventually replaced by her ''[[Rugrats]]'' co-star [[E. G. Daily]].{{cite web | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jul/20/news/cl-55085 | title=A Former Phantom, a Future Noah | work=The Los Angeles Times | date=20 July 2001 | author=Lacher, Irene}} The director of the successful [[Babe (film)|first movie]], Chris Noonan, had no involvement in ''Babe: Pig in the City''; directorial duties were handled by George Miller and Noonan was reportedly not even invited to the premiere Australian screening.{{Cite web|title=Babe: Pig in the City|url=https://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/babe-pig-in-the-city|access-date=2022-01-16|website=www.ozmovies.com.au}} Prior to the film's theatrical release, it was originally rated [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|PG]] by the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]].{{cite web | url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2001/0720/072001.us.us.3.html | title=Have 'G' movies lost their innocence? | publisher=The Christian Science Monitor | date=20 July 2001 | author=Marks, Alexandra}} The TV spots for the film's theatrical release mentioned this rating, as did a promotional poster. By the time the film was released in theaters it had been re-rated as G due to the film being re-edited and submitted again for review. ''Babe: Pig in the City'' takes place in an imaginative, fantasy-like [[metropolis]]. The aesthetic is notably reminiscent of [[Return to Oz|Oz]].{{cite web | url=https://junkee.com/babe-pig-in-the-city/299986 | title=I Fear 'Babe: Pig In The City' As Much As I Love It | publisher=Junkee | date=30 June 2021 | author=Earp, Joseph}} The city has numerous styles of architecture from around the world. It also has a variety of waterways, noticeable by the hotel at which Babe stays. The downtown area appears to be situated on an island not dissimilar to [[Manhattan Island]]. The Downtown Skyline features numerous landmarks such as the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]], the [[Sears Tower]], the [[Chrysler Building]], the [[Empire State Building]], the [[IDS Center]], the [[MetLife Building]], the [[Sydney Opera House]], the [[Hollywood sign]], the [[Golden Gate Bridge]], the [[Fernsehturm Berlin]], [[Big Ben]], [[St. Basil's Cathedral]] of [[Moscow]]'s [[Red Square]], the [[Statue of Liberty]], the [[Eiffel Tower]], the ''[[Christ the Redeemer (statue)|Christ the Redeemer]]'' statue, among others. The DVD covers feature a similar but different city of San Francisco. ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Babe: Pig in the City'' opened on November 25, 1998, during [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] weekend, ranking in fifth place behind ''[[A Bug's Life]]'', ''[[The Rugrats Movie]]'', ''[[Enemy of the State (film)|Enemy of the State]]'' and ''[[The Waterboy]]''.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/98553190/pig-in-hot-water/ |title=Pig in hot water |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221012022242/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/98553190/pig-in-hot-water/ |date=December 1, 1998 |access-date=October 12, 2022 |archive-date=October 12, 2022 |page=7 |publisher=[[Leader-Telegram]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |url-status=live}} {{Open access}} The film made $6.4 million during its opening weekend, combined with $8.5 million from its first five days of release.{{cite news |last=Hinckley |first=David |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/111150020/disneys-lovable-bugs-bring-home-the/ |title=Disney's lovable bugs bring home the bacon |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221012020703/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/111150020/disneys-lovable-bugs-bring-home-the/ |date=November 30, 1998 |access-date=October 12, 2022 |archive-date=October 12, 2022 |page=426 |work=Daily News Staff Writer |publisher=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |url-status=live}} {{Open access}} ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has 65% approval rating based on 65 reviews, with a [[weighted arithmetic mean|weighted average]] of 6.24/10.{{cite web | title = Babe: Pig in the City | website = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/babe_pig_in_the_city/ | access-date = 2019-07-08}} Audiences surveyed by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film a grade "B" on scale of A+ to F.{{cite web |url= https://cinemascore.com/publicsearch/index/title/ |title= Cinemascore |url-status= dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20181220122629/https://cinemascore.com/publicsearch/index/title/ |archive-date= 2018-12-20 |access-date= 2019-04-06 }} On Metacritic the film carries a score of 68, based on 25 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/movie/babe-pig-in-the-city| title= Babe: Pig in the City Reviews| website= Metacritic}} On release the film received poor reviews by most critics, receiving the lowest marks; most believed the sequel had lost the innocence of the original. [[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'s [[Andrew Collins (broadcaster)|Andrew Collins]] said, "Where Babe brought deep-rooted joy, the sequel brings fidgety depression" and awarded the film one star.{{Cite web|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/reviews/babe-pig-city-review/|title=Babe: Pig In The City|website=Empire}} [[Janet Maslin]] of [[The New York Times]] said, "It will work as a sequel only hard-core ''Babe'' fans willing to follow this four-legged hero (or heroine, as Babe obviously is in some scenes) anywhere. Had ''Pig in the City'' been made first, it by no means could have prompted a sequel of its own."https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/20/movies/film-review-goodbye-green-acres-hello-wild-side.html {{Dead link|date=February 2022}} American film critic [[Gene Siskel]] named it as his choice for the best movie of 1998.{{Cite web|date=2011-10-22|title=Obituary: Gene Siskel|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-gene-siskel-1072625.html|access-date=2020-12-15|website=The Independent|language=en}} [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film four out of four stars and said it was even better than the original: "''Babe'' was a movie where everything led up to the big sheepherding contest. ''Babe: Pig in the City'' is not so plot-bound, although it has the required assortment of villains, chases and close calls. It is more of a wonderment, lolling in its enchanting images-- original, delightful, and funny." He concluded: "I liked ''Babe'' for all the usual reasons, but I like ''Babe: Pig in the City'' more, and not for any of the usual reasons, because here is a movie utterly bereft of usual reasons."{{cite web | date = 20 July 2001 | first = Roger | last = Ebert | author-link = Roger Ebert | title = Babe: Pig In The City | url = https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/babe-pig-in-the-city-1998 }} It made Ebert's list of the best films of the year.{{Cite news |last=Ebert |first=Roger |date=December 31, 1998 |title=The Best Films of 1998 |work=Chicago-Sun Times |url=https://www.rogerebert.com/roger-ebert/the-best-10-movies-of-1998}} Pat Graham of the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' said it "may be the best commercial film of 1998."{{Cite news |last=Graham |first=Patrick |date=December 10, 1998 |title=Babe: Pig in the City |work=[[Chicago Reader]] |url=https://chicagoreader.com/film/babe-pig-in-the-city/}} In the decades since ''Babe: Pig in the City''{{'s}} release, the movie has developed a [[cult following]]. [[Tom Waits]] expressed appreciation for the film during a 2010 interview with ''[[Mojo Magazine]]''.{{cite web|last=Zborowski |first=James |url=http://betweensympathyanddetachment.blogspot.com/2010/06/artists-crossing-mediums.html |title=Between Sympathy and Detachment: Artists crossing mediums |publisher=Betweensympathyanddetachment.blogspot.com |date=2010-06-27 |access-date=2014-08-15}} Radio personality/podcaster [[Jesse Thorn]] has also praised the film.{{cite web|author=Bullseye with Jesse Thorn |url=https://soundcloud.com/bullseye-with-jesse-thorn/outshot-babe |title=The Outshot: Babe: Pig in the City by Bullseye with Jesse Thorn on SoundCloud - Hear the world's sounds |publisher=Soundcloud.com |date=2013-11-04 |access-date=2014-08-15 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140922170431/https://soundcloud.com/bullseye-with-jesse-thorn/outshot-babe |archive-date=2014-09-22 }} Luke Buckmaster of ''[[The Guardian]]'' called it "brilliant" and "underrated."{{Cite news |last=Buckmaster |first=Luke |date=February 27, 2016 |title=Babe: Pig in the city rewatched -- talking pig returns in grossly underrated sequel |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/28/babe-pig-in-the-city-rewatched-talking-pig-returns-in-grossly-underrated-sequel}} ==Awards== [[Peter Gabriel]]'s "That'll Do", written and composed by [[Randy Newman]], was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]] at the [[71st Academy Awards]].{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/109931529/oscar-dotes-on-shakespeare-in-love/ |title=Oscar dotes on 'Shakespeare in Love,' 'Saving Private Ryan' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220921125604/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/109931529/oscar-dotes-on-shakespeare-in-love/ |newspaper=[[Detroit Free Press]] |page=2 |date=March 22, 1999 |access-date=September 21, 2022 |archive-date=September 21, 2022 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |url-status=live}} {{Open access}} ==Soundtrack== The [[film score|musical score]] for ''Babe: Pig in the City'' was composed by Nigel Westlake, who previously wrote the music for ''[[Babe (film)|Babe]].'' A soundtrack album was released on 24 November 1998 by [[Geffen Records]] featuring Westlake's score, music inspired to the movie...as well as sound clips taken from film. The soundtrack also includes source music such as "[[Chattanooga Choo Choo]]" by [[Glenn Miller]] and "[[That's Amore]]" by [[Dean Martin]]. Additional tracks include the Academy Award-nominated theme song "That'll Do" and a song sung by [[Elizabeth Daily]], the voice of Babe. {{Track listing | extra_column = Artist | extra1 = Peter Gabriel Featuring Paddy Maloney* And The Black Dyke Band | title1 = That'll Do | length1 = 3:53 | extra2 = Melbourne Symphony Orchestra | title2 = Babe: A Pig In The City | length2 = 1:22 | extra3 = Melbourne Symphony Orchestra | title3 = The Returning Hero | length3 = 1:16 | extra4 = [[Edith Piaf]] | title4 = [[Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien]] | length4 = 2:19 | extra5 = Glenn Miller & His Orchestra* With Tex Beneke & The Modernaires With Unknown Artist | title5 = Chattanooga Choo-Choo | length5 = 3:14 | extra6 = Melbourne Symphony Orchestra | title6 = Scram, This Is Not A Farm! | length6 = 2:27 | extra7 = Dean Martin | title7 = That's Amore | length7 = 3:07 | extra8 = Unknown Artist | title8 = Three Blind Mice | length8 = 0:42 | extra9 = Melbourne Symphony Orchestra | title9 = A Pig Gets Wise | length9 = 1:17 | extra10 = The Mavericks | title10 = Are You Lonesome Tonight | length10 = 3:00 | extra11 = The Chieftains Featuring The Black Dyke Mills Band | title11 = Protected By Angels | length11 = 3:39 | extra12 = The Terem Quartet* | title12 = The Big City (Two Step Nadya) | length12 = 3:12 | extra13 = Melbourne Symphony Orchestra | title13 = Babe's Lament | length13 = 2:38 | extra14 = E.G. Daily | title14 = A Heart That's True | length14 = 4:00 | extra15 = Melbourne Symphony Orchestra | title15 = The End | length15 = 1:26 | extra16 = James Watson And The Black Dyke Mills Band | title16 = That'll Do (Instrumental) | length16 = 4:00 }} ==Home media== The film was released on [[VHS]], [[DVD]] (in both [[widescreen]] and [[pan and scan]] formats), and [[laserdisc]] on 4 May 1999. On 22 May 2001, the film was released on DVD as a 2-pack with the original ''[[Babe (film)|Babe]]''. On September 23, 2003, it was re-released on DVD as part of "The Complete Adventure Two-Movie Pig Pack" in its separate widescreen and pan and scan formats. On November 12, 2004, it was re-released onto DVD as part of a Family Double Feature, which includes ''Babe'' with the widescreen and the pan and scan versions of the film. On May 7, 2013, it was released on [[Blu-ray]] for the 15th Anniversary Edition of the film's release and re-released on Blu-ray by Fabulous Films Limited in UK on June 17, 2017.{{citation needed|date=February 2020}} ==Video game== In 2006, a universally-panned video game based on the film was released on [[PlayStation 2]].{{cite web|url=https://www.gamepressure.com/games/babe/zb1cbe|title=Babe PS2|publisher=Game Pressure|access-date=2019-10-13}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} {{Commons category}} Studio: studio = | genre = [[Glam rock]], [[soundtrack]] | length = 1:12:09 | label = [[Fontana Records|Fontana Records London]] | producer = Randall Poster, [[Todd Haynes]], [[Michael Stipe]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} Although the character of Brian Slade is heavily based on [[David Bowie]], Bowie vetoed the proposal that his songs appear in the film.<ref name=":0"/> However, as producer of [[Lou Reed]]'s 1972 ''[[Transformer (Lou Reed album)|Transformer]]'' album, his backing vocals (mainly consisting of "bum-bum-bum"s and "ooh-ooh"s) can be heard on "[[Satellite of Love]]". The finished soundtrack includes songs by [[glam rock]] and glam-influenced bands, past and present. The English musicians who played under the name The Venus in Furs on the soundtrack were [[Radiohead]]'s [[Thom Yorke]] and [[Jonny Greenwood]], Craig "Clune" McClune of [[David Gray (musician)|David Gray]]'s band, [[Suede (band)|Suede]]'s [[Bernard Butler]], and [[Roxy Music]]'s [[Andy Mackay]]. The American musicians who played as Curt Wild's [[Wylde Ratttz]] on the soundtrack were [[The Stooges]]' [[Ron Asheton]], [[Sonic Youth]]'s [[Thurston Moore]] and [[Steve Shelley]], [[Minutemen (band)|Minutemen]]'s [[Mike Watt]], [[Gumball (band)|Gumball]]'s [[Don Fleming (musician)|Don Fleming]], and [[Mark Arm]] of [[Mudhoney (band)|Mudhoney]]. The soundtrack features new songs written for the film by [[Pulp (band)|Pulp]], [[Shudder to Think]] and [[Grant Lee Buffalo]],<ref name="AMG">Erlewine, Stephen Thomas. [{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r380467|pure_url=yes}} "''Velvet Goldmine'': Review"], AllMusic.com.</ref> as well as many early glam rock compositions, both covers and original versions. The Venus in Furs covers several Roxy Music songs with Thom Yorke channeling [[Bryan Ferry]] on vocals,<ref name="AMG" /> [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]] covers [[T. Rex (band)|T. Rex]]'s "[[20th Century Boy]]," Wylde Ratttz and Ewan McGregor cover The Stooges' "T.V. Eye" and "Gimme Danger", and [[Teenage Fanclub]] and [[Donna Matthews]] cover the [[New York Dolls]]' "[[Personality Crisis (song)|Personality Crisis]]". Lou Reed, [[Brian Eno]], T. Rex, and [[Steve Harley]] songs from the period are also included. The album is rounded out by a piece of [[Carter Burwell]]'s score. All three members of the band Placebo also appeared in the film, with [[Brian Molko]] and [[Steve Hewitt]] playing members of the Flaming Creatures (Malcolm and Billy respectively) and [[Stefan Olsdal]] playing Polly Small's bassist. Another member of the Flaming Creatures, Pearl, was played by Xavior (Paul Wilkinson), former lead singer of [[Romo]] band [[Dex Dexter (band)|DexDexTer]] and later a keyboard player for Placebo and [[Rachel Stamp]]. ;Track listing # [[Brian Eno]]: "Needle in the Camel's Eye" (Brian Eno, [[Phil Manzanera]]) – 3:09 # Shudder to Think: "Hot One" ([[Nathan Larson (musician)|Nathan Larson]], Shudder to Think) (Based on a lot of David Bowie's glam work, mostly "[[Time (David Bowie song)|Time]]") – 3:04 # [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]]: "20th Century Boy" (T. Asheton, Osterberg Jr.) – performed by Wylde Ratttz, vocals by Ewan McGregor #"Ballad of Maxwell Demon" (Wedren, Shudder to Think) – performed by Shudder to Think #"The Whole Shebang" (Phillips) – performed by Grant Lee Buffalo #"Symphony No. 6 in A Minor" (Gustav Mahler) – performed by Czech Philharmonic Orchestra #"Get in the Groove" (James Timothy Shaw) – performed by The Mighty Hannibal #"Ladytron" (Ferry) – performed by The Venus In Furs, vocals by Thom Yorke #"We Are the Boys" (Cocker, Banks, Doyle, Mackey, Webber) – performed by Pulp #"Cosmic Dancer" (Bolan) – performed by T. Rex #"Virginia Plain" (Ferry) – performed by Roxy Music #"Personality Crisis" (Johansen, Thunders) – performed by Teenage Fanclub & Donna Matthews #"Satellite of Love" (Reed) – performed by Lou Reed #"Diamond Meadows" (Bolan) – performed by T. Rex #"Bitters End" (Ferry) – performed by Paul Kimble #"Baby's on Fire" (Eno) – performed by The Venus in Furs, vocals by Jonathan Rhys Meyers #"My Unclean" (R. Asheton, Mark Arm) – performed by Wylde Ratz, vocals by Ewan McGregor #"Bitter-Sweet" (Mackay, Ferry) – performed by The Venus in Furs, vocals by Thom Yorke #"20th Century Boy" (Bolan) – performed by Placebo #"Dead Finks Don't Talk" (Eno) -performed by Brian Eno #"Gimme Danger" (Iggy Pop, [[James Williamson (musician)|James Williamson]]) – performed by The Venus in Furs, vocals by Ewan McGregor #"Tumbling Down" (Harley) – performed by The Venus in Furs, vocals by Jonathan Rhys Meyers #"2HB" (Ferry) – performed by The Venus in Furs, vocals by Paul Kimble #"Make Me Smile (Come Up and See Me)" (Harley) – performed by Steve Harley & Cockney Rebel ==Reception== ===Box office=== The film opened in the United Kingdom on 23 October 1998 and grossed over $700,000.<ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=14 December 1998|page=72|title=British biz at the box office}}</ref> It was released in the United States on 6 November 1998 in 85 venues, grossing $301,787 in its opening weekend and ranking sixteenth at the box office, and fifth among the week's new releases.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=1998&wknd=45&p=.htm | title=Weekend Box Office Results for November 6–8, 1998 | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Amazon.com]] | date=9 November 1998 | access-date=3 December 2016}}</ref> It would ultimately gross $1,053,788 in the United States and Canada and $4,313,644 worldwide.<ref name=numbers>{{cite web | url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Velvet-Goldmine#tab=summary | title=''Velvet Goldmine'' (1998) – Financial Information | work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]] | access-date=3 December 2016}}</ref> ===Critical response=== ''Velvet Goldmine'' received mixed to positive reviews from critics. On [[review aggregator]] website Rotten Tomatoes, the film has a 60% rating based on 47 reviews, with an average of 6.5/10. The critical consensus reads: "''Velvet Goldmine'' takes a visual and narrative approach befitting its larger-than-life subject, although it's still disappointingly less than the sum of its parts".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/velvet_goldmine/ | title=''Velvet Goldmine'' (1998) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Flixster]] | access-date=18 May 2022}}</ref> Metacritic reports a 65 out of 100 score based on 25 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/velvet-goldmine | title=''Velvet Goldmine'' Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | access-date=3 December 2016}}</ref> [[Janet Maslin]], having seen the film at the [[New York Film Festival]], made it a "NYT Critics' Pick," calling it a "dazzlingly surreal" rock version of "''Citizen Kane'' with an extraterrestrial [[Citizen Kane#"Rosebud"|Rosebud]]" and saying it "brilliantly reimagines the glam rock ‘70s as a brave new world of electrifying theatricality and sexual possibility, to the point where identifying precise figures in this neo-psychedelic landscape is almost beside the point. ''Velvet Goldmine'' tells a story the way [[opera]]s do: blazing with exquisite yet abstract passions, and with quite a lot to look at on the side."<ref>{{cite web| title= Glittering Ode to the Days of Ziggy Stardust| url= http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9805E4DB103AF932A35753C1A96E958260 | date= 1 October 1998 | first= Janet| last= Maslin | work= The New York Times | access-date=2012-01-27}}</ref> According to [[Peter Travers]], "Haynes creates ''Velvet Goldmine''...with a masturbatory fervor that demands dead-on details" and "fashions a structure out of ''Citizen Kane''"; it's a film that "works best as a feast of sight and sound,...re-creating an era as a gorgeous carnal dream,...celebrat[ing] the art of the possible."<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Travers |first=Peter |date=18 April 2001 |title=Velvet Goldmine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/velvet-goldmine-20010418 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208063812/https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/movie-reviews/velvet-goldmine-251470/ |archive-date=December 8, 2021 |access-date=2012-01-27 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref> In a less enthusiastic review, [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film two out of four stars and found its plot too discursive and confusingly assorted because of how it "bogs down in the apparatus of the search for Slade" by clumsily using scenes from ''Citizen Kane''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ebert|first=Roger|author-link=Roger Ebert|title=Velvet Goldmine Movie Review & Film Summary (1998)|newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=6 November 1998|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/velvet-goldmine-1998|access-date=9 August 2013}}</ref> David Sterritt from ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' wrote "The music and camera work are dazzling, and the story has solid sociological insights into a fascinating pop-culture period."<ref name="Ryll 2014">{{cite web |author=Alexander Ryll |title=Essential Gay Themed Films To Watch, Velvet Goldmine |url=http://gay-themed-films.com/watch-velvet-goldmine/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207162814/http://gay-themed-films.com/watch-velvet-goldmine/ |archive-date=February 7, 2015 |access-date=7 February 2015 |website=Gay Essential}}</ref> In a retrospective review, ''[[Slant Magazine]]'''s Jeremiah Kipp gave ''Velvet Goldmine'' four out of four stars and said that, although unsupportive critics may be "terrified of a movie with so many ideas", the film successfully shows a "melancholic ode to freedom, and those who fight for it through art", because of Haynes' detailed imagery and the cast's "expressive, soulful performances".<ref>{{cite web|last=Kipp|first=Jeremiah|date=25 March 2004|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/velvet-goldmine/940|title=Velvet Goldmine|publisher=[[Slant Magazine]]|access-date=9 August 2013}}</ref> Scott Tobias of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' felt that Haynes' appropriation of structural elements from ''Citizen Kane'' is the film's "masterstroke", as it helps "evoke the glam rock movement without destroying the all-important mystique that sustains it." Tobias argued that, like Haynes' [[Bob Dylan]]-inspired 2007 film ''[[I'm Not There]]'', ''Velvet Goldmine'' deals with a famously enigmatic figure indirectly through allusion and imagery, and consequently succeeds more than a simpler biopic could.<ref>{{cite web| title= The New Cult Canon: ''Velvet Goldmine'' | url= http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-new-cult-canon-velvet-goldmine,23422/ | date= 5 February 2009 | first= Scott | last= Tobias | publisher= The A.V. Club | access-date=2012-01-27}}</ref> In an interview with [[GQ]], [[Jonathan Rhys Meyers]] criticized the decision to use a different actor to play Tommy Stone at the end of the film: "... it's very hard for the audience to get that, which I think, I'm not quite sure did we make the right move there. Because I would have preferred to play Tommy Stone myself. You would have got more of the connection."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Saxena |first=Jaya |title=Jonathan Rhys Meyers Has Only Seen Velvet Goldmine Once |url=https://www.gq.com/story/jonathan-rhys-meyers-velvet-goldmine-interview |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=GQ |date=20 June 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> ==Home media== Since its 1999 [[DVD]] release, the film has become a [[Cult film|cult classic]]<ref name="Encore New York">{{Cite news |date=August 1, 2008 |title=Glam's Velvet Gold |work=Encore Monthly |url=http://encoremag.com/new-york/articles/282/glam-velvet-goldmine-mccarren |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004213320/http://encoremag.com/new-york/articles/282/glam-velvet-goldmine-mccarren |archive-date=October 4, 2011}}</ref> and has been described as having "an obsessive following among younger audiences."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/movies/la-ca-second-look-20120108,0,2837697.story |title='Velvet Goldmine,' 'Mildred Pierce' capture director's interests |date= 12 January 2012 |first= Dennis |last = Lim |work=L.A. Times}}</ref> Haynes said in a 2007 interview, "A film that had the hardest time, at least initially, was ''Velvet Goldmine'', and it's the film that seems to mean the most to a lot of teenagers and young people, who are just obsessed with that movie. They're exactly who I was thinking about when I made ''Velvet Goldmine'', but it just didn't get to them the first time around."<ref name="A.V. Club">{{Cite web |last=Murray |first=Noel |date=2007-11-20 |title=Todd Haynes |url=https://www.avclub.com/todd-haynes-1798212805 |access-date= |website=The A.V. Club |language=en}}</ref> A [[Blu-ray]] was released in [[Blu-ray#Region codes|Region A]] on 13 December 2011, and includes a newly recorded commentary track by Haynes and Vachon. In it, Haynes thanks the fansites for helping him compile the notes for the commentary.<ref name="Indiewire">{{Cite news |last=Gilchrist |first=Todd |date=December 16, 2011 |title=Todd Haynes Thanks The Fans For Helping Him Remember The Details & Backstories Of 'Velvet Goldmine' |work=IndieWire |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/todd-haynes-talks-velvet-goldmine-blu-ray-re-release |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109051225/http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/todd-haynes-talks-velvet-goldmine-blu-ray-re-release |archive-date=January 9, 2012}}</ref> The soundtrack to Velvet Goldmine was released on [[Phonograph record|vinyl]] in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Velvet Goldmine Original Soundtrack – MVD Entertainment Group B2B |url=https://mvdb2b.com/s/VelvetGoldmineOriginalSoundtrack/MVD9442LP |access-date=2022-05-09 |website=mvdb2b.com}}</ref> ==Awards and nominations== * [[1998 Cannes Film Festival]] – Best Artistic Contribution – Todd Haynes; also nominated for [[Palme d'Or]]<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/4918/year/1998.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Velvet Goldmine |access-date=2009-10-02|work=festival-cannes.com}}</ref> * [[71st Academy Awards|Academy Awards]] – nominated for [[Academy Award for Costume Design|Best Costume Design]] ([[Sandy Powell (costume designer)|Sandy Powell]])<ref>{{cite web |title=The 71st Academy Awards |url=https://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1999 |website=oscars.org |access-date=13 October 2022}}</ref> * [[52nd British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Award]] – Best Costume Design – Best Costume Design – Sandy Powell; nominated for Best Make Up/Hair (Peter King)<ref>{{cite web |title=Film in 1999 |url=https://awards.bafta.org/award/1999/film |website=awards.bafta.org |access-date=13 October 2022}}</ref> * [[14th Independent Spirit Awards|1999 Independent Spirit Awards]] – Best Cinematography – Maryse Alberti; nominated for Best Director (Todd Haynes) and Best Feature<ref>{{cite news |title="Affliction" Tops Spirit Award Nominations; "Monster," "Art," and "Sex" Also Nab Numerous Nods |url=https://www.indiewire.com/1999/01/affliction-tops-spirit-award-nominations-monster-art-and-sex-also-nab-numerous-nods-82417/ |access-date=13 October 2022 |work=IndieWire |date=January 8, 1999}}</ref> * 1998 [[Edinburgh International Film Festival]] – Channel 4 Director's Award – Todd Haynes * [[GLAAD Media Award]]s – Outstanding Film (Limited Release)<ref>{{cite news |title=GLAAD bows media noms |url=https://variety.com/1999/film/news/glaad-bows-media-noms-1117490393/ |access-date=13 October 2022 |work=Variety |date=January 19, 1999}}</ref> ==Connections to other works== {{More citations needed section|date=January 2012}} * The film's title takes its name from David Bowie's song "[[Velvet Goldmine (song)|Velvet Goldmine]]". * The film's disclaimer reads "Although what you are about to see is a work of fiction, it should nevertheless be played at maximum volume," an allusion to Bowie's ''Ziggy Stardust'' album, which contains the legend: "To be played at maximum volume." * The name of the lead character, Brian Slade, is an allusion to the 1970s glam band, [[Slade]]. Slade's persona "Maxwell Demon" was named after [[Brian Eno]]'s first band, which itself was influenced by [[James Clerk Maxwell]]'s thought experiment character, "[[Maxwell's demon]]". * Wild's backing band, The Rats, shares its name with one of [[Mick Ronson]]'s earliest groups.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Velvet Goldmine – The Movie |url=http://www.5years.com/velvetfilm2.htm |access-date= |website=www.5years.com}}</ref> It also alludes to Iggy Pop's band, [[The Stooges]] in that both words share a similar meaning ("rat" and "stooge" both being terms for someone who is an informer). * The scene where couples are shown walking into the Sombrero Club on New Year's Eve 1969 is similar to a shot of people entering a party from Welles' film ''[[The Magnificent Ambersons (film)|The Magnificent Ambersons]]''.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} * Maxwell Demon's guitarist shares his name, Trevor, with Bowie's [[The Spiders from Mars]] bassist [[Trevor Bolder]], and his last name is Finn, as [[T. Rex (band)|T. Rex]] percussionist [[Mickey Finn (musician)|Mickey Finn]]. * "Venus in Furs" is a reference to a Velvet Underground [[Venus in Furs (song)|song of the same name]], whose title and lyrics in turn reference a [[Venus in Furs|novel of that name]] by [[Leopold von Sacher-Masoch]]. * ''[[Flaming Creatures]]'' is also the name of [[Jack Smith (film director)|Jack Smith]]'s seminal piece of gay cinema. * Much of the script consists of quotations from various works of [[Oscar Wilde]], and several of the scenes involving the character Jack Fairy reference the novels of [[Jean Genet]]. * The bleak, [[dystopian]] feel of the action taking place in 1984 alludes to the novel ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'' by [[George Orwell]], to Bowie's own dystopian [[1984 (song)|song of the same name]], and to Bowie's reinvention of himself as a mainstream entertainer during the [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]] and [[Margaret Thatcher|Thatcher]] era. * The "pantomime dame" from the vaudeville troupe is played by influential dancer [[Lindsay Kemp]], a former teacher of Bowie's who collaborated with him on several music videos, including "[[John, I'm Only Dancing]]". * The little girl on the train is reading "[[Antigonish (poem)|Antigonish]]" (a poem by [[William Hughes Mearns]]), which was inspiration for [[David Bowie]]'s "[[The Man Who Sold the World (song)|The Man Who Sold The World]]". * Arthur Stuart's boss has [[mydriasis]] in his left eye, much like Bowie's. * "The Ballad of Maxwell Demon" contains the lyrics: "The boys from Quadrant 44 with their vicious metal hounds never come 'round here no more," referencing [[Ray Bradbury]]'s [[utopian and dystopian fiction|dystopian novel]], ''[[Fahrenheit 451]]''. This is likely an allusion to Bowie basing some songs on the album ''[[Diamond Dogs]]'' on the dystopian novel ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]''. *The scene near the middle of the film that portrays Slade and Wild about to make love as [[Barbie]] Dolls, pays homage to Haynes' earlier work in ''[[Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story]]'', which was acted out primarily with the dolls. ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite journal|last=Padva |first=Gilad |title=Claiming Lost Gay Youth, Embracing Femininostalgia: Todd Haynes's ''Dottie Gets Spanked'' and ''Velvet Goldmine''. |url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1057/9781137266347_5 |journal=Queer Nostalgia in Cinema and Pop Culture |pages=72–97 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |year=2014 |doi=10.1057/9781137266347_5 |isbn=978-1-137-26633-0}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0120879}} * {{Mojo title|velvetgoldmine}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|velvet_goldmine}} * The Personals: Improvisations on Romance in the Golden Years
Distributor: distributor = Fanlight Productions | runtime = 40 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''The Personals''''' (also known as '''''The Personals: Improvisations on Romance in the Golden Years''''') is a 1998 American [[short film|short]] [[documentary film]] directed by {{ill|Keiko Ibi|ja|伊比恵子}} about a Jewish [[senior citizens]]' theatre group in [[New York City]]. In 1999, it won an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] at the [[71st Academy Awards]] for [[Academy Award for Best Documentary (Short Subject)|Documentary Short Subject]].<ref name="Oscars1999">{{Cite news |url= http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1999 |title=The 71st Academy Awards (1999) Nominees and Winners |access-date=November 19, 2011 |work=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]|publisher=AMPAS}}</ref> ==Cast== * Gloria Bobrofsky as Performer * Abram Calderon as Performer * Deborah Ehrlich as Performer * Seth Glassman as Performer * Harold Gordon as Performer * Harold Krinsky as Performer * Ruth Krinsky as Performer * Moe Kronberg as Performer * Fred Schechter as Performer * Rose Straub as Performer * Shirley Tavel as Performer * Selma Wernick as Performer ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://fanlight.com/catalog/films/272_tp.php ''The Personals''] at Fanlight Productions *{{IMDb title|id=0176018|title=The Personals}} {{Academy Award Best Documentary Short}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Personals, The}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:1990s short documentary films]] [[Category:American short documentary films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Best Documentary Short Subject Academy Award winners]] [[Category:Documentary films about theatre]] [[Category:Documentary films about old age]] [[Category:Documentary films about Jews and Judaism in the United States]] [[Category:Documentary films about New York City]] [[Category:1998 independent films]] [[Category:1990s English-language films]] [[Category:1990s American films]] {{arts-documentary-film-stub}}

Studio: studio = [[Blue Sky Studios]] | released = {{Film date|November 2, 1998}} | runtime = 7 minutes 15 seconds | country = United States }} '''''Bunny''''' is a 1998 American [[computer-animated]] short film by [[Chris Wedge]] and produced by [[Blue Sky Studios]].<ref>[https://filmschoolrejects.com/watch-3-early-animated-shorts-by-epic-director-chris-wedge-including-the-oscar-winner-bunny-b343405aacc/ Watch 3 Early Animated Shorts by 'Epic' Director Chris Wedge Including the Oscar Winner 'Bunny' - Film School Rejects]</ref> It was featured on the original 2-disc special edition DVD release of ''[[Ice Age (2002 film)|Ice Age]]'' from 2002<ref>{{cite news|last=Horn|first=Steven|title=Ice Age|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2002/10/29/ice-age?page=2|access-date=June 2, 2013|newspaper=IGN|date=October 29, 2002}}</ref> and the 2006 "Super-Cool Edition" re-release to coincide with the release of ''[[Ice Age: The Meltdown]]''. Influenced by the classic ''Uncle Wiggily'' illustrations by [[Lansing Campbell]], the short features the music of [[Tom Waits]]. ''Bunny'' won the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]] in 1998 <ref>{{cite web|title=The 71st Academy Awards (1999) Nominees and Winners|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/71st-winners.html|publisher=The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|access-date=January 23, 2013|date=March 21, 1999}}</ref> as well a Golden Nica at the [[Prix Ars Electronica]].<ref>{{cite web|title=1999 Prix Winners: Computer Animation / Visual Effects|url=http://www.aec.at/prix/en/winners/1999-prix-gewinner-computer-animation-visual-effects/|publisher=Prix Ars Electronica|access-date=January 23, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304193142/http://www.aec.at/prix/en/winners/1999-prix-gewinner-computer-animation-visual-effects/|archive-date=March 4, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> ==Plot== Bunny, an elderly female rabbit, lives alone in a small cabin in the forest. While baking a cake one night, she is continually bothered by a large [[moth]] that keeps flying around her kitchen. No matter what she does, she cannot get rid of the intruder; she is especially annoyed when it runs into a photograph, taken many years ago, of herself and her late husband on their wedding day. Eventually, she knocks it into the cake batter, which she quickly and angrily pours into a pan and shoves into the oven. She then sets the kitchen timer and falls asleep, only to be awakened by loud rumblings and a blue-white light coming from the oven, whose door soon falls open. Crawling inside, she finds herself face-to-face with the moth and begins to float through an otherworldly space toward the source of the light, with a pair of giant moth wings sprouting from her back to propel her as the insect leads her along. She is soon revealed to be among dozens of moths being drawn to the light. The film ends with a close-up of the wedding photo, which comes to life as the younger Bunny nestles her head contentedly on her husband's shoulder; the shadows and reflections of two of the moths play across the image as well.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/1999Bunny 1999 Bunny: Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming: Internet Archive]</ref> During his introduction to the film on the ''Ice Age'' DVD, Wedge offers his take of these events: Bunny dies in her sleep, and the oven serves as a gateway to the afterlife. Her spirit is instinctively drawn into it, as a moth going toward a bright light, and is finally reunited with her husband.<ref>[https://animatedviews.com/2002/ice-age-2-disc-special-edition/ Ice Age: Disc Special Edition - Animated Views]</ref> ==Accolades== *1999: [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]] (won) <ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jTQODmIlTAw Short Film Winners: 1999 Oscars]</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://web.archive.org/web/20210209220748/http://blueskystudios.com/films/bunny/}} * {{bcdb title|id=29252|title=Bunny}} * {{IMDb title|id=0179011|title=Bunny}} * {{tcmdb title|521922|Bunny}} {{Navboxes | title = Awards for ''Bunny'' | list1 = {{AcademyAwardBestAnimatedShortFilm 1981–2000}} {{Annie Award for Best Animated Short Subject}} }} {{Chris Wedge}} {{Blue Sky Studios}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:1998 computer-animated films]] [[Category:1998 short films]] [[Category:1990s American animated films]] [[Category:1990s animated short films]] [[Category:Animated films about rabbits and hares]] [[Category:Animated films about insects]] [[Category:Animated films without speech]] [[Category:Best Animated Short Academy Award winners]] [[Category:Best Animated Short Subject Annie Award winners]] [[Category:Blue Sky Studios short films]] [[Category:20th Century Fox short films]] [[Category:Computer-animated short films]] [[Category:Films directed by Chris Wedge]] [[Category:Films about the afterlife]] [[Category:Films about death]]

Studio: studio = | genre = | length = {{Duration|m=67|s=52}} | label = [[Hollywood Records]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The [[film score]] was written and produced by [[Danny Elfman]]. It won the [[Satellite Award for Best Original Score|Golden Satellite Award]] and was also nominated by the Las Vegas Film Critics. ==Release== ===Marketing=== To promote ''Sleepy Hollow'', Paramount Pictures featured the [[Trailer (promotion)|film's trailer]] at [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] in August 1999.<ref>{{cite news | author = Amid Amidi | url = http://www.awn.com/mag/issue4.06/4.06pages/amidicomic/amidicomiccon.php3 | title = San Diego Comic-Con '99: More Than Fat, Sweaty Guys | work = [[Animation World Network]] | date = September 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110612060407/http://www.awn.com/mag/issue4.06/4.06pages/amidicomic/amidicomiccon.php3 | archive-date = June 12, 2011 | url-status=dead | df = mdy-all }}</ref> The following October, the studio launched a website, which ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described as being the "most ambitious [[Internet marketing|online launch]] of a motion picture to date."<ref name="online" /> The site (sleepyhollowmovie.com) offered visitors live video chats with several of the filmmakers hosted by [[Yahoo! Movies]] and enabled them to send postcards, view photos, trailers and a six-minute behind-the-scenes featurette edited from a broadcast that aired on ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]''. Extensive tours of 10 sets were offered, where visitors were able to roam around photographs, including the sets for the entire town of Sleepy Hollow, forest, church, graveyard and covered bridge. Arthur Cohen, president of worldwide marketing for Paramount, explained that the "Web-friendly" pre-release reports<ref name="online">{{cite news | author = Marc Graser | url = https://www.variety.com/article/VR1117757625 | title = Par gets peppy with 'Sleepy' online | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = November 1, 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref> from websites such as [[Ain't It Cool News]] and [[Dark Horizons]]<ref>{{cite news | author = Marc Graser | url = https://www.variety.com/article/VR1117756810 | title = .Com before storm | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = October 19, 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Drew McWeeny | url =http://www.aint-it-cool-news.com/display.cgi?id=1976| title = Moriarty Reports On Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow | work = [[Ain't It Cool News]] | date = August 26, 1998 | access-date = November 1, 2010 | author-link = Drew McWeeny}}</ref> encouraged the studio to create the site.<ref name="online" /> In the weeks pre-dating the release of ''Sleepy Hollow'', a toy line was marketed by [[McFarlane Toys]].<ref>{{cite news | author = David Kilmer | url =http://www.awn.com/news/licensing/mcfarlane-toys-releases-sleepy-hollow-figures| title = McFarlane Toys releases Sleepy Hollow figures| work = [[Animation World Network]] | date = November 19, 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref> [[Simon & Schuster]] also published ''The Art of Sleepy Hollow'' ({{ISBN|0671036572}}), which included the film's screenplay and an introduction by Tim Burton.<ref>{{cite news | isbn = 0671036572 | title = The Art of Sleepy Hollow | last1 = Walker | first1 = Andrew Kevin | year = 1999 }}</ref> A [[novelization]], also published by Simon & Schuster, was written by [[Peter Lerangis]].<ref>{{cite news | isbn = 0671036653 | title = Sleepy Hollow: A Novelization | last1 = Lerangis | first1 = Peter | year = 1999 }}</ref> ===Box office=== ''Sleepy Hollow'' was released in the United States on November 19, 1999, in 3,069 theaters, grossing $30,060,467 in its opening weekend<ref name=box>{{cite web |title=Sleepy Hollow (1999) |url=https://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=sleepyhollow.htm |website=[[Box Office Mojo]] |access-date=March 29, 2016}}</ref> at the No. 2 spot behind ''[[The World Is Not Enough]]''.<ref>{{cite news | author = Dade Hayes | url = https://www.variety.com/article/VR1117758270 | title = B.O. shaken, stirred by Bond | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = November 21, 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref> It would drop into fourth place behind the latter film, ''[[Toy Story 2]]'' and ''[[End of Days (film)|End of Days]]'' the following weekend.<ref name="Stampede">{{cite news |last=Lyman |first=Rick |title=Those Toys Are Leaders In Box-Office Stampede |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/29/movies/those-toys-are-leaders-in-box-office-stampede.html |access-date=March 25, 2022 |work=The New York Times |date=November 29, 1999 |archive-date=March 19, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220319232310/https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/29/movies/those-toys-are-leaders-in-box-office-stampede.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Sleepy Hollow'' eventually earned $101,068,340 in domestic gross, and $106 million in foreign sales, coming to a worldwide total of $207,068,340.<ref name=numbers /> ===Home media=== Paramount Home Video first released ''Sleepy Hollow'' on [[DVD]] and [[VHS]] in the United States on May 23, 2000.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00003CX5A | title = Sleepy Hollow | website = Amazon | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref> The [[HD DVD]] release came in July 2006,<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000GTJT16 | title = Sleepy Hollow (HD DVD) | website = Amazon | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref> while the film was released on [[Blu-ray Disc]] two years later, in June 2008.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000I0QM0E | title = Sleepy Hollow (Blu-ray) | website = Amazon | access-date = November 1, 2010}}</ref> An unofficial video game adaptation of the film titled ''Cursed Fates: The Headless Horseman'' was released by Fenomen Games and [[Big Fish Games]] on January 6, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fenomen Games|title=Cursed Fates: The Headless Horseman Collector's Edition|url=https://www.bigfishgames.com/games/8017/cursed-fates-headless-horseman-ce/?pc|website=Big Fish Games|publisher=Big Fish Games, Inc}}</ref> For the 20th anniversary, Paramount Home Entertainment released a Blu-ray digibook with a photobook containing the original story on September 24, 2019.<ref>{{Citation|title=Watch Sleepy Hollow {{!}} DVD/Blu-ray or Streaming {{!}} Paramount Movies|url=https://www.paramountmovies.com/movies/sleepy-hollow|language=en|access-date=February 26, 2020}}</ref> ===Reception=== Film [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 70% of critics gave the film a positive review based on 123 reviews with an average rating of 6.3/10. The site's critics consensus states, "It isn't Tim Burton's best work, but ''Sleepy Hollow'' entertains with its stunning visuals and creepy atmosphere."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/sleepy_hollow |title=Sleepy Hollow (1999) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media|Fandango]] |access-date=April 16, 2019}}</ref> [[Metacritic]], another review aggregator, assigned the film a weighted average score of 65 out of 100 based on 35 reviews from mainstream critics, considered to be "generally favorable".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/movie/sleepy-hollow |title=Sleepy Hollow Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |access-date=March 29, 2016}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B−" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web |url=https://cinemascore.com/publicsearch/index/title/ |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com |access-date=December 18, 2018 |archive-date=December 20, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181220122629/https://cinemascore.com/publicsearch/index/title/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] praised Johnny Depp's performance and Tim Burton's methods of visual design. "Johnny Depp is an actor able to disappear into characters," Ebert continued, "never more readily than in one of Burton's films."<ref>{{cite news | author = Roger Ebert | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19991119/REVIEWS/911190303 | title = Sleepy Hollow | work = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date = November 19, 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010 | author-link = Roger Ebert}}</ref> [[Richard Corliss]] wrote, in his review for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', "Burton's richest, prettiest, weirdest [film] since ''[[Batman Returns]]''. The simple story bends to his twists, freeing him for an exercise in high style."<ref>{{cite magazine | author = Richard Corliss | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,992634,00.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080302224633/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,992634,00.html | url-status = dead | archive-date = March 2, 2008 | title = Tim Burton's Tricky Treat | magazine = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date = November 22, 1999 | access-date = November 1, 2010 | author-link = Richard Corliss}}</ref> [[David Sterritt]] of ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' highly praised Burton's filmmaking and the high-spirited acting of cast, but believed Andrew Kevin Walker's writing was too repetitious and formulaic for the third act.<ref>{{cite news | author = David Sterritt | url = http://www.csmonitor.com/durable/1999/11/19/fp19s1-csm.shtml | title = New Releases| work = [[The Christian Science Monitor]] | date = November 19, 1999 | access-date = November 4, 2010 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20000229234512/http://www.csmonitor.com/durable/1999/11/19/fp19s1-csm.shtml |archive-date = February 29, 2000 | author-link = David Sterritt}}</ref> [[Owen Gleiberman]] from ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote ''Sleepy Hollow'' is "a choppily plotted crowd-pleaser that lacks the seductive, freakazoid alchemy of Burton's best work." Gleiberman compared the film to ''[[The Mummy (1999 film)|The Mummy]]'', and said "it feels like every high-powered action climax of the last 10 years. Personally, I'd rather see Burton so intoxicated by a movie that he lost his head."<ref>{{cite magazine | author = Owen Gleiberman | url = https://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,271815,00.html | title = Dead Heads| magazine = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | date = November 26, 1999 | access-date = November 4, 2010 | author-link = Owen Gleiberman}}</ref> [[Andrew Johnston (critic)|Andrew Johnston]] of ''[[Time Out New York]]'' wrote: "Like the best of Burton's films, ''Sleepy Hollow'' takes place in a world so richly imagined that, despite its abundant terrors, you can't help wanting to step through the screen."<ref>Time Out New York, Nov 18–25, 1999, p. 121.</ref> [[Mick LaSalle]], writing in the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', criticized Burton's perceived image as a creative artist. "All ''Sleepy Hollow'' has going for it is art direction, and even in that it falls back on [[cliché]]."<ref>{{cite news | author = Mick LaSalle | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/1999/11/19/DD79156.DTL&type=movies | title = 'Sleepy Hollow' a Yawner| work = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date = November 19, 1999 | access-date = November 7, 2010 | author-link = Mick LaSalle}}</ref> [[That Guy with the Glasses|Doug Walker]] linked the film to the [[Hammer Films]] style of horror cinematography, considering it an homage to those movies, comparing the usage of dignified British actors, choices in color and movie sets and character relations. Walker gave it the merit of recreating the "very specific genre" of Hammer Films, citing the skill and "clever casting" Burton used to manage this.<ref>{{cite news | author = Doug Walker | url = http://thatguywiththeglasses.com/videolinks/thatguywiththeglasses/nostalgia-critic/45329-is-sleepy-hollow-secretly-brilliant | title = Is 'Sleepy Hollow' Secretly Brilliant?| date = October 28, 2014 | access-date = November 26, 2014 | author-link = That Guy with the Glasses}}</ref> [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] from the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' called ''Sleepy Hollow'' "a ravishing visual experience, a pretty good vehicle for some talented American and English actors," but concluded that the film was a missed opportunity to depict an actual representation of the short story. "Burton's fidelity is exclusively to the period feeling he gets from disreputable Hammer horror films and a few images culled from ''[[The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad|Ichabod and Mr. Toad]]''. When it comes to one of America's great stories, Burton obviously couldn't care less."<ref>{{cite news | author = Jonathan Rosenbaum | url = http://www.jonathanrosenbaum.net/?p=6437 | title = Hollow Rendition [on Sleepy Hollow]| work = [[Chicago Reader]] | date = November 26, 1999 | access-date = November 7, 2010 | author-link = Jonathan Rosenbaum}}</ref> ==Accolades== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="95%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" |+ style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Premiere | released = 1998 (UK) | runtime = 7 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English }} '''''Humdrum''''' is a 1998 British animated comedy short film directed by Peter Peake.[https://www.allmovie.com/movie/humdrum-v300853 AllMovie] It was released in 1998 and produced by [[Aardman Animations]] and received an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]] and a [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] nomination in the same category.{{Cite web|url=http://www.telepathy.co.uk/aardman/news/|title=Aardman Animations - Latest News}} ==Plot summary== The film features two anonymous Scottish-accented [[Shadow play|Shadow Puppets]] (voiced by [[Jack Docherty]] and [[Moray Hunter]]) who are sitting around a table with nothing to do. They explore and reject several options including watching television (the only thing on is 'some weird animation thing'), listening to the radio (but 'it's all the same rubbish these days' - in this case [[La Cucaracha]]) and playing chess (the white pieces have been eaten due to a bet). This is briefly interrupted when the doorbell rings and one character answers it to find a pesky dog (who is, in fact, a double-glazing salesman) before the other persuades him to enter into a game of shadow puppets. The first character is frustrated by his acquaintance's appalling representation of a [[cow]] and later his failure to recognize a rather fantastic [[rabbit]] (His misled guesses include a 'fireman chasing an igloo' and an 'Otter with two sausage strapped to his head'). After an amusing outburst from the poor fellow, his annoying partner accuses him of being 'shirty'. This leads him to explode, furiously crying "I'm stuck indoors playing 'Guess the misshapen beast' with someone who clearly wouldn't recognise a rabbit if it came to his house for tea, said '[[Bugs Bunny|What's up Doc?]]' and started burrowing into his head! There are blind people with no fingers who are better at shadow puppets than you! No wonder I'm a tad miffed!" An awkward silence follows this, until the doorbell rings and the first character goes to answer it and finds the second character's 'cow' shadow puppet, which moos. Despite being disappointed with being wrong about a cow's appearance, he simply responds to this with a cheery "Not today, thank you." and closes the door in front of the camera, thus ending the animation.[http://bestanimatedshort.blogspot.com/2012/04/best-animated-short-1999.html Best Animated Short: Best Animated Short - 1999] ==Cast== * [[Jack Docherty]] * [[Moray Hunter]][https://www.bcdb.com/cartoon/38998-Humdrum BCDB] ==Film technique== The film employs a distinctive [[stop motion]] [[cutout animation]] technique to animate the shadow puppets,[https://www.awn.com/animationworld/fresh-festivals-october-1999s-film-reviews Fresh From the Festivals: October 1999's Film Reviews-AWN] making them move in ways that traditional shadow puppets cannot but retaining the impression of being projected onto everyday backgrounds. ==Credits== *Lighting Camera: Andy MacCormack, Jeremy Hogg, Toby Howell *Design: Peter Peake *Music: [[Andy Price]] *Editor: Nick Upton *Script Doctor: [[Richard Goleszowski]] *Dubbing Editors: James Mather, Ben Jones *Dialogue Editor: Tamsin Parry *Sparks: John Bradley, John Truckle *Technical Boffs: Janet Legg, Alan Yates *Titles: Marc Day *Cutting Room Assistant: Maggie O'Connor *Production Assistants: Lisa Pavitt, Margaret House-Hayes *Heap Big Thanks to: The Puppet Factory, Big Fat Studios, [[Pete Atkin]], Maxine Guest, Claire Jennings, Terry Krejzl, Helen Nabarro, Lynda Ware *Producers: [[Carla Shelley]], Michael Rose *Associate Producer: Julie Lockhart *Executive Producers: [[Peter Lord]], [[David Sproxton]] *Written and Directed by: Peter Peake {{Cite web |url=http://www.keyframeonline.com/Animation/Humdrum/755/ |title=Humdrum |access-date=7 October 2018 |archive-date=12 October 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151012201035/http://www.keyframeonline.com/Animation/Humdrum/755/ |url-status=dead }} ==See also== *[[List of stop-motion films]] *[[Silhouette animation]] (a similar technique but with the light coming from behind) ==External links== *[https://www.aardman.com/work/humdrum-clip/ Homepage] *{{IMDb title|0192145}} *[https://vimeo.com/91125489 ''Humdrum'' Studio: studio = | genre = [[Orchestra]]l [[film score]] | length = 51:22 | label = [[Varèse Sarabande]] | producer = Jerry Goldsmith, Paul Verhoeven | chronology = Jerry Goldsmith soundtrack | prev_title = [[The 13th Warrior]] | prev_year = 1999 | next_title = [[Along Came a Spider (film)|Along Came a Spider]] | next_year = 2001 }} The soundtrack for ''Hollow Man'' was composed by [[Jerry Goldsmith]], his third collaboration with Verhoeven after ''[[Total Recall (1990 film)|Total Recall]]'' (1990) and ''[[Basic Instinct]]'' (1992). [[Varèse Sarabande]] released it on [[Compact Disc|CD]] on July 25, 2000.<ref name="AllMusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/hollow-man-mw0000084683|title=Hollow Man - Jerry Goldsmith|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=April 9, 2014}}</ref> [[Filmtracks.com]] found there to be two distinct [[Motif (music)|motifs]]: the "transitional motif" of "bass thumping and [an] array of prickling [[Effects unit|electronic effects]] that slowly increase their pace and volume as the scenes [of invisibility] progress", heard in "Isabelle Comes Back" and "This Is Science"; and the "rambling [[piano]] and bass-element [[ostinato]] heard for the violent chasing" in both "The Elevator" and "The Big Climb".<ref name="Filmtracks">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/hollow_man.html|title=Filmtracks: Hollow Man (Jerry Goldsmith)|publisher=[[Filmtracks.com]]|date=August 3, 2000|access-date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> The site pointed out "the pulsating piano, [[Woodwind instrument|woodwind]], and electronic rhythm from [''Basic Instinct''] underneath a meandering, disembodied theme for high [[String section|strings]] not much unlike [''[[The Haunting (1999 film)|The Haunting]]'']", and judged that the "action bursts, especially with the [[Electronic drum|drum pad]] and [[synthesizer]] combos" were akin to Goldsmith's use of those elements in ''Total Recall''.<ref name="Filmtracks"/> Overall, the site felt the score was "over the top", calling it "pieced together from other Goldsmith scores" and derivative while citing the first and second tracks as highlights.<ref name="Filmtracks"/> ==Release== Despite a negative response from critics, ''Hollow Man'' debuted at #1 ahead of ''[[Nutty Professor II: The Klumps]]'' with $26.4 million in its opening weekend. During this time, the film achieved the second-highest August opening weekend, behind ''[[The Sixth Sense]]'' (1999).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/112370249/hollow-man-makes-visible-showing-at/ |title='Hollow Man' makes visible showing at weekend box office |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221101170157/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/112370249/hollow-man-makes-visible-showing-at/ |date=August 7, 2000 |access-date=November 1, 2022 |archive-date=November 1, 2022 |page=25 |publisher=[[The Star Press]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |url-status=live}} {{Open access}}</ref> It was the first film since ''[[Mission: Impossible 2]]'' to top the box office for multiple weeks. After fifteen weeks of release, ''Hollow Man'' had grossed in excess of $73.2 million in North America and just over $117 million elsewhere, making a total of $190.2 million worldwide, against its $95 million production budget.<ref name=box-office/> It was Verhoeven's biggest hit since ''[[Basic Instinct]]'' (1992).<ref name="Keesey"/> ==Reception== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film holds an approval rating of 26% based on 118 reviews, with an average rating of 4.35/10. The site's critics consensus states: "Despite awesome special effects, ''Hollow Man'' falls short of other films directed by Paul Verhoeven. This flick over time degenerates into a typical horror film."<ref name="tomatoes">[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hollow_man/ ''Hollow Man'']. [[Rotten Tomatoes]]. [[Flixster]].</ref> At [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 24 out of 100, based on from 35 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".<ref name="Metacritic">{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/hollow-man|title=Hollow Man Reviews |website= [[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|access-date=April 9, 2014}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "C" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web |url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com}}</ref> While some critics criticized the plot and acting, with some claiming it contains hallmarks of [[slasher film]]s<ref name="Ebert">{{cite web | url = http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/hollow-man-2000 | title = Hollow Man | author = Roger Ebert | date = August 4, 2000 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130602102131/http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/hollow-man-2000 | archive-date = 2013-06-02 }}</ref> and misogynistic undertones,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.randomhouse.ca/hazlitt/feature/flesh-blood-showgirls-hollow-man-and-paul-verhoeven%E2%80%99s-legacy|title=Flesh & Blood: On Showgirls, Hollow Man, and Paul Verhoeven's Legacy {{pipe}} Hazlitt|author=Marsh, Calum|publisher=[[Random House Canada]]|date=May 24, 2013|access-date=April 9, 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413143952/http://www.randomhouse.ca/hazlitt/feature/flesh-blood-showgirls-hollow-man-and-paul-verhoeven%E2%80%99s-legacy|archive-date=April 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> most critics praised the visual effects employed in making [[Kevin Bacon]] appear to be invisible, which earned the film a nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Visual Effects]] at the [[73rd Academy Awards|2001 Academy Awards]]. [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film 2 stars out of 4, and complained that Verhoeven wasted potential by taking an invisible man and doing nothing more than having him go berserk. While ultimately feeling that the film is merely a slasher film with a science gimmick, Ebert praised the special effects, calling them "intriguing" and "astonishing", but felt the film lacked the "imagination and wit" of Verhoven's best films.<ref name="Ebert"/> The film received three nominations at the 2000 [[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]]: Worst On-Screen Group (the scientists), Worst Screenplay for a Film That Grossed over $100 Million Using Hollywood Math, and Most Unintentionally Funny Movie, but lost to ''[[Battlefield Earth (film)|Battlefield Earth]]'' and ''[[Gone in 60 Seconds (2000 film)|Gone in 60 Seconds]]'', respectively.<ref>{{cite web |title=Past Winners Database |url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/2000/2000st.htm |website=The Envelope at LA Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070105221207/http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/2000/2000st.htm |access-date=24 September 2019|archive-date=January 5, 2007 }}</ref> The film was also nominated for both [[Saturn Award for Best Science Fiction Film|Best Science Fiction Film]] and [[Saturn Award for Best Music|Best Music]] at the [[Saturn Awards]] and won [[Saturn Award for Best Special Effects|Best Special Effects]]. A fake review attributed to [[David Manning (fictitious writer)|David Manning]] was revealed in late 2001 as a hoax, created by [[Sony]] to fake publicity for the film.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1368666.stm | title = Sony admits using fake reviewer | work= [[BBC News]] | date = June 4, 2001 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20030727124918/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1368666.stm | archive-date = 2003-07-27 }}</ref> Verhoeven was not happy with the movie. In 2013, he told ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'':{{cquote|I decided after ''Hollow Man'', this is a movie, the first movie that I made that I thought I should not have made. It made money and this and that, but it really is not me anymore. I think many other people could have done that. I don't think many people could have made ''[[RoboCop]]'' that way, or either ''[[Starship Troopers (film)|Starship Troopers]]''. But ''Hollow Man'', I thought there might have been 20 directors in Hollywood who could have done that. I felt depressed with myself after 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tribeca-paul-verhoeven-tricked-hollywood-444642|title=Tribeca: Paul Verhoeven on 'Tricked' and Hollywood - Hollywood Reporter|author=Zakarin, Jordan|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 23, 2013|access-date=April 10, 2014}}</ref>}} As of 2022, ''Hollow Man'' was Verhoeven's final film produced by a major American production company. ==Home media== ''Hollow Man'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[VHS]] in North America by [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment|Columbia TriStar Home Entertainment]] on January 2, 2001. It was released with its [[widescreen]] theatrical [[Aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] of 1.85:1 and included various special features, including two [[Audio commentary|audio commentaries]]—one with Verhoeven, writer [[Andrew W. Marlowe]] and Kevin Bacon, and another with composer [[Jerry Goldsmith]] and the isolated score of the film; the [[HBO]] making-of [[featurette]] "''Hollow Man'': Anatomy of a Thriller"; 15 mini-featurettes on the making of the film, several detailing [[storyboard]]s of progress shots with commentary; three deleted scenes with commentary by Verhoeven; visual effects [[picture-in-picture]] comparisons of the raw footage with the final scene; cast and crew biographies; a [[Teaser campaign|teaser]] and a [[Trailer (promotion)|theatrical trailer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dvdcompare.net/comparisons/film.php?fid=546|title=Rewind @ www.dvdcompare.net - Hollow Man (2000)|publisher=The Rewind Network|access-date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> In the years that followed, both a deluxe [[Superbit]] edition was made, as well as a [[director's cut]] of the film, which restored nearly seven minutes of footage—primarily extended cuts of existing scenes including Linda and Matthew in bed, the rape scene, Sebastian killing the dog and the aftermath of Sarah being suspicious of Sebastian.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movie-censorship.com/report.php?ID=4544|title=Hollow Man (Comparison: Theatrical Version - Director's Cut)|publisher=Movie-Censorship.com|access-date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> The director's cut version of the film was released on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] October 16, 2007 with a [[1080p]] resolution.<ref name="Blu-ray">{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Hollow-Man-Blu-ray/539/|title=Hollow Man Blu-ray: Director's Cut|publisher=Blu-ray.com|access-date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> Although lacking any commentaries, it restores most other special features.<ref name="Blu-ray"/> A two-disc double pack including the stand-alone sequel ''[[Hollow Man 2]]'' was released on DVD in 2006 while Mill Creek Entertainment released the Blu-ray version on March 26, 2013. Mill Creek also released the director's cut in their Dark Passengers 8 movie DVD collection on October 1, 2013, 24 Horror DVD collection on March 7, 2017, and The 6 Degrees Blu-ray collection on April 3, 2018. On July 8, 2019, both films were released on Blu-ray Collector's Edition by 88 Films, including the theatrical cut of the first film.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Hollow-Man-and-Hollow-Man-2-Blu-ray/232763|title=Hollow Man and Hollow Man 2 (Collector's Edition)|publisher=88 Films (Blu-ray.com)|access-date=November 24, 2020}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0164052|Hollow Man}} * {{tcmdb title|443262|Hollow Man}} * {{mojo title|hollowman|Hollow Man}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|hollow_man|Hollow Man}} * {{Metacritic film|title=Hollow Man}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.bamlawca.com/pdf/sonynot.pdf | title=Official Court Notice | work= [[David Manning (fictitious writer)|David Manning]] settlement | publisher= Blumenthal, Nordrehaug & Bhowmik | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206042739/http://bamlawca.com/pdf/sonynot.pdf | archive-date= 2009-02-06 | access-date=2011-05-23}} {{Paul Verhoeven}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hollow Man}} [[Category:2000 films]] [[Category:2000 horror films]] [[Category:2000s science fiction horror films]] [[Category:2000s monster movies]] [[Category:American science fiction horror films]] [[Category:American monster movies]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:Films about invisibility]] [[Category:Films about mass murder]] [[Category:Films about scientists]] [[Category:Films based on The Invisible Man]] [[Category:Films produced by Douglas Wick]] [[Category:Films directed by Paul Verhoeven]] [[Category:Films scored by Jerry Goldsmith]] [[Category:Films set in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Films shot in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films shot in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:English-language German films]] [[Category:German science fiction horror films]] [[Category:2000s English-language films]] [[Category:2000s American films]] [[Category:2000s German films]] [[Category:Films produced by Alan Marshall (producer)]]
