[[Soundtrack.Net]]{{cite web|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''|url=http://www.scorenotes.com/reviewArchive/charlie.html|website=[[Soundtrack.Net]]|access-date=January 19, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906075003/http://www.soundtrack.net/album/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|archive-date=September 6, 2015}} |rev6Score = {{Rating|4|5}} }} [[Danny Elfman]], similar to Tim Burton, had no emotional attachment to 1971's ''[[Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory]]''.{{cite book|last=Bond|first=Jeff|title=Danse Macabre: 25 Years of Danny Elfman and Tim Burton|publisher=[[Warner Records|Warner Bros. Records Inc.]]|year=2010|pages=203–209|chapter=The Golden Ticket: Adventures in Loompaland|url=https://archive.org/details/the-golden-ticket/mode/2up}} According to Elfman, "I had no trouble divorcing myself from those [original] songs. I've dealt with that a couple of times. You know you're dealing with something that's going to make a lot of people angry, and you just can't think about it."{{cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/article/2011/07/22/danny-elfman-tim-burton-interview/|title= Danny Elfman on Tim Burton, Gus Van Sant, and why it's so hard to sing in Russian: An EW Q&A|date=July 22, 2011|last=Anderson|first=Kyle|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|access-date=January 5, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220105224324/https://ew.com/article/2011/07/22/danny-elfman-tim-burton-interview/|archive-date=January 5, 2022|url-status=live}} Because the Oompa-Loompa musical numbers would require complex choreography and be shot on set, Elfman had to compose those songs before filming began. Elfman also composed the songs simultaneously alongside the music from ''[[Corpse Bride]]''.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.filmscoremonthly.com/backissues/viewissue.cfm?issueID=110|last=Adams|first=Doug|date=July 2005|title=Morality Plays|pages=34–39|magazine=[[Film Score Monthly]]|access-date=January 19, 2022|archive-url=https://archive.org/details/Film_Score_Monthly_Volume_10_Issue_04_2005_07_Vineyard_Haven_US/page/n31/mode/2up|archive-date=December 15, 2019|url-status=live}} It was decided at an early stage that Elfman would be providing the vocals for all the Oompa-Loompas, a decision justified by the identical nature of the Oompa-Loompas, with pitch changes and modulations to represent different singers.{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2005-jul-03-ca-popeye3-story.html|title=A return to format for Elfman|last=Hochman|first=Steve|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 3, 2005|access-date=November 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210909000449/https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2005-jul-03-ca-popeye3-story.html|archive-date=September 9, 2021|url-status=live|url-access=subscription}} ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' marks the first time since 1993's ''[[The Nightmare Before Christmas]]'' that Elfman contributed to a film score using written songs and his vocals. The first song composed was "Augustus Gloop", being done as a [[Bollywood]] spectacle per [[Deep Roy]]'s suggestion. Elfman recounted, "my original approach was to find a style of music and apply that to all the songs. Tim was like, 'No, no, no, no, no... we're going to completely mix it up!' I said, 'Great, let's go.'" Per Burton's suggestion, the Oompa-Loompa songs would each reflect a different style of music: "Violet Beauregarde" is 1970s [[funk]], "Veruca Salt" is 1960s [[bubblegum pop|bubblegum]] and [[psychedelic pop]], and "Mike Teavee" is a tribute to late-1970s [[hard rock]], particularly [[Queen (band)|Queen]], and early 1980s [[Glam metal|hair bands]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2005/06/22/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-meets-danny-elfman?amp=1|title=''Charlie And The Chocolate Factory'' Meets Danny Elfman|date=June 22, 2005|website=[[IGN]]|access-date=December 5, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211205110730/https://www.ign.com/articles/2005/06/22/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-meets-danny-elfman?amp=1|archive-date=December 5, 2021|url-status=live}} All four songs utilize lyrics direct from [[Roald Dahl]]'s book; as such, the lyrics are credited to Dahl. Rather than using the book's songs in their entirety, Elfman selected specific verses, as he believed using them unabridged would have made each song ten minutes long. "Violet Beauregarde" was the only song that required a partial rewrite, as the song in the book was about a girl who chewed gum rather than Violet Beauregarde herself. The only other song to require vocal performances was "Wonka's Welcome Song", which was written in collaboration with the film's screenwriter John August.{{cite web|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/os-xpm-2005-07-18-namescp18-story.html|title=It's music to Oompa Loompa by|last=Lowman|first=Rob|date=July 18, 2005|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|via=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|access-date=November 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210717110948/https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/os-xpm-2005-07-18-namescp18-story.html|archive-date=July 17, 2021|url-status=live}} In addition to the Oompa-Loompa songs, Elfman created an entire underscore for the film being based around three primary themes: a gentle family theme for the Buckets, generally set in upper [[Woodwind instrument|woodwinds]]; a mystical, string-driven [[waltz]] for Willy Wonka; and a hyper-upbeat factory theme for full orchestra, Elfman's homemade [[synthesizer]] samples and the diminutive chanting voices of the Oompa-Loompas. Elfman and Burton differed on their ideas for the main title music, as Elfman imagined something more dreamy while Burton wanted something energetic. [[Richard Strauss]]' ''[[Also sprach Zarathustra]]'' plays during a sequence in the film as a direct reference to ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/popculture/chocolate-factory-tasty-surprise-wbna8547003|title={{'}}''Chocolate Factory''{{'}} is a tasty surprise|last=Harti|first=John|date=July 14, 2005|work=[[Today (American TV program)|Today]]|access-date=November 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202124408/https://www.today.com/popculture/chocolate-factory-tasty-surprise-wbna8547003|archive-date=December 2, 2020|url-status=live}} When introducing himself to the golden ticket winners, Wonka quotes "[[Good Morning Starshine]]" from the 1967 musical ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.popartmachine.com/where-did-willy-wonkas-good-morning-starshine-the-earth-says-hello-come-from/|title= Where Did Willy Wonka's "Good Morning Starshine, The Earth Says Hello!" Come From?|last=Forrester|first=Julia|date=March 26, 2019|work=Pop Art Machine|access-date=February 15, 2022}} The original motion picture soundtrack was released on July 12, 2005, by [[Warner Sunset Records]].{{cite web|url=https://genius.com/albums/Danny-elfman/Charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-original-motion-picture-soundtrack|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack''|website=[[Genius (website)|Genius]]|access-date=November 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211014222807/https://genius.com/albums/Danny-elfman/Charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-original-motion-picture-soundtrack|archive-date=October 14, 2021|url-status=live}} Doug Adams of ''[[Film Score Monthly]]'' said of the Oompa-Loompa songs: "Each piece includes something the others don't, rhythms or hooks or harmonies that in Elfman's inimitable way seem like deconstructions and wholly original concepts at the same time." [[Filmtracks.com]] called the soundtrack a "rhythmically driven affair" because of the mechanical nature of the factory, a departure from Elfman's penchant for quieter heartbreaking themes. "Wonka's Welcome Song" received a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]] nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Song Written for Visual Media|Best Song Written for Visual Media]].{{cite book|last=Umland|first=Samuel J.|date=2015|title=The Tim Burton Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3jWCCgAAQBAJ|location=London|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|page=20|isbn=9780810892002}} Elfman would later cite ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' as being one of the most fun projects he had been involved with. In 2010, thirteen previously unreleased tracks were included as part of the ''Danny Elfman & Tim Burton 25th Anniversary Music Box''. In addition to those tracks, instrumentals of "Wonka's Welcome Song" and the Oompa-Loompa songs were included, as well as several demos.{{cite web|url=https://www.slashfilm.com/511407/cool-stuff-danny-elfman-tim-burton-25th-anniversary-music-box-limited-edition-set/|title=Cool Stuff: Danny Elfman & Tim Burton 25th Anniversary Music Box Limited Edition Set|last=Sciretta|first=Peter|date=October 5, 2010|work=[[/Film]]|access-date=December 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210909014445/https://www.slashfilm.com/511407/cool-stuff-danny-elfman-tim-burton-25th-anniversary-music-box-limited-edition-set/|archive-date=September 9, 2021|url-status=live}} ==Release== [[File:Charlie and the Chocolate Factory Premier (30402126) (2).jpg|thumb|right|[[Helena Bonham Carter]] is photographed at the film's London premiere.]] ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' had its [[premiere]] at the [[Grauman's Chinese Theatre]] on July 10, 2005, where money for the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation|Make-a-Wish Foundation]] was raised.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/12/nyregion/premieres-to-avoid-charlie-and-the-tripe-factory.html|last=Robertson|first=Campbell|title=Premieres to Avoid: Charlie and the Tripe Factory|date=July 12, 2005|work=[[The New York Times]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210211172049/https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/12/nyregion/premieres-to-avoid-charlie-and-the-tripe-factory.html|archive-date=February 11, 2021|url-status=live|url-access=registration}} The film was released in the United States on July 15, 2005, in 3,770 theaters,{{cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl659260929/?ref_=bo_tt_gr_1|title=Charlie and the Chocolate Factory Box Office Mojo|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|access-date=December 6, 2021}} including [[IMAX]] theaters.{{cite news|last=Tillson|first=Tamsen|url=https://variety.com/2004/film/markets-festivals/wonka-pic-blown-up-1117915125/|title='Wonka' pic blown up|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 16, 2004|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009231823/https://variety.com/2004/film/markets-festivals/wonka-pic-blown-up-1117915125/|archive-date=October 9, 2021|url-status=live}} In the United Kingdom, the premiere was held on July 17 at [[Leicester Square]], only ten days after the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|July 7 London bombings]].{{cite news|last=Gaydos|first=Steven|url=https://variety.com/2005/scene/vpage/sweet-on-london-1117926448/|title=Sweet on London|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 24, 2005|access-date=June 30, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220630043626/https://variety.com/2005/scene/vpage/sweet-on-london-1117926448/|archive-date=June 30, 2022|url-status=live}} It was released nationwide on July 29 in 531 theaters.{{cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl2011792897/weekend/|title=Charlie and the Chocolate Factory Box Office Mojo|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|access-date=December 6, 2021}} The release of ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' rekindled public interest in Roald Dahl's 1964 book, which appeared on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]] from July 3 to October 23, 2005.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/10/books/arts/childrens-best-sellers-july-10-2005.html|title=Children's Best Sellers: July 10, 2005|date=July 10, 2005|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191102142630/https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/10/books/arts/childrens-best-sellers-july-10-2005.html|archive-date=November 2, 2019|url-status=live|url-access=registration}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/23/books/arts/childrenss-best-sellers-october-23-2005.html|title=Children's Best Sellers: October 23, 2005|date=October 23, 2005|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529191502/https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/23/books/arts/childrenss-best-sellers-october-23-2005.html|archive-date=May 29, 2015|url-status=live|url-access=registration}} Burton's film also reignited interest in the [[Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory|1971 film adaptation]].{{cite web|date=July 18, 2005|first=Cara|last=Anna|title=When it comes to Bucket, Ostrum just can't kick it|url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2005/jul/18/when-it-comes-to-bucket-ostrum-just-cant-kick-it/|website=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|access-date=June 25, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220626135234/https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2005/jul/18/when-it-comes-to-bucket-ostrum-just-cant-kick-it/|archive-date=June 26, 2022|url-status=live}} According to Michael Böllner, who portrayed Augustus Gloop in ''Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory'', the first adaptation was largely unheard of in Germany until Burton's version was released.{{cite AV media|url=https://wgntv.com/news/deans-list/stars-of-willy-wonka-and-the-chocolate-factory-celebrate-50-years/|title=Stars of 'Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory' celebrate 50 years|first=Dean|last=Richards|date=June 28, 2021|type=Video|publisher=[[WGN-TV]]|access-date=June 25, 2022|language=en|time=2:52|quote=The film is not famous in Germany. Nobody knows the film until the version with Johnny Depp came out.}} ===Marketing=== Early in the development of ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' in February 2000, Warner Bros. announced their intention of marketing the film with a [[Broadway theatre]] musical after release. The studio reiterated their interest in May 2003; however, the idea was postponed by the time filming began in June 2004. The teaser poster for ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' was released in November 2004, with the teaser trailer premiering the following month in front of showings of ''[[The Polar Express (film)|The Polar Express]]''.{{cite news|last=Norton|first=Shaun|url=https://insidepulse.com/2004/11/09/28883/|title=Teaser Poster for ''Chocolate Factory'' Online|work=Inside Pulse|date=November 9, 2004|access-date=December 6, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190425034225/https://insidepulse.com/2004/11/09/28883/|archive-date=April 25, 2019|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/dec/10/news1|title= In brief: First look at ''War of the Worlds''|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=December 10, 2004|access-date=December 6, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002004807/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/dec/10/news1|archive-date=October 2, 2016|url-status=live|url-access=registration}} The longer theatrical trailer was made available in May 2005 exclusively via [[Moviefone]] before its theatrical debut alongside screenings of ''[[Madagascar (2005 film)|Madagascar]]''.{{cite web|url=https://johnaugust.com/2005/holy-buckets-its-the-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-trailer|title=Holy Buckets! It's the ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' trailer!|date=May 26, 2005|last=August|first=John|author-link=John August|website=John August|access-date=August 31, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210507051526/https://johnaugust.com/2005/holy-buckets-its-the-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-trailer|archive-date=May 7, 2021|url-status=live}} The main [[tie-in]] for ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' focused on [[the Willy Wonka Candy Company]], a division of [[Nestlé]]. A small range of [[Wonka Bar]]s were launched, utilizing their prominence in the film.{{cite news|last=Archerd|first=Army|author-link=Army Archerd|url=https://variety.com/2004/film/columns/rowlands-takes-time-from-key-to-heal-1117903990/|title=Rowlands takes time from 'Key' to heal|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=April 24, 2004|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009232131/https://variety.com/2004/film/columns/rowlands-takes-time-from-key-to-heal-1117903990/|archive-date=October 9, 2021|url-status=live}} Echoing the central storyline of the film, Wonka candies introduced their own Golden Ticket contest in Wonka products, including Wonka Bars, [[Wonka Donutz|Donutz]], [[Laffy Taffy]], [[Nerds (candy)|Nerds]], and [[SweeTarts]]. The contest's prizes included a trip to Europe, a tour of an animation studio, a trip to a sports camp, a shopping spree, and $10,000 cash.{{cite web|url=https://csnews.com/nestle-asks-whos-got-golden-ticket|title=Nestle Asks, Who's Got a Golden Ticket?|date=June 22, 2005|website=Convenience Store News|access-date=June 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220627120912/https://csnews.com/nestle-asks-whos-got-golden-ticket|archive-date=June 27, 2022|url-status=live}} 60 million packages of candy participated in the sweepstakes.{{cite web|url=https://adage.com/article/madisonvine-news/charlie-chocolate-factory-sweet-tie-ins/45988|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' Goes Sweet with Tie-Ins|date=June 8, 2005|last=Stanley|first=T.L.|website=[[Ad Age]]|access-date=August 21, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220822142202/https://adage.com/article/madisonvine-news/charlie-chocolate-factory-sweet-tie-ins/45988|archive-date=August 22, 2022|url-status=live}} The contest officially began on June 28 following its announcement on the ''[[Today (American TV program)|Today Show]]'', and the first winners were announced on July 8.{{cite press release|url=https://www.warnerbros.com/news/press-releases/grand-prize-winner-named-warner-bros-pictures’-“charlie-and-chocolate-factory”-golden|title=Grand Prize Winner Named In Warner Bros. Pictures' ''Charlie And The Chocolate Factory'' Golden Ticket Sweepstakes|date=July 8, 2005|publisher=[[Warner Bros.]]|access-date=August 21, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210803005215/https://www.warnerbros.com/news/press-releases/grand-prize-winner-named-warner-bros-pictures%E2%80%99-%E2%80%9Ccharlie-and-chocolate-factory%E2%80%9D-golden|archive-date=August 3, 2021|url-status=live}} In addition to Nestlé, [[Hostess Brands|Hostess]] introduced Chocolicious WonkaCakes, and [[Wendy's]] released ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''-themed kids' meal toys. Other partners included [[Carlson (company)|Carlson]], [[Penguin Group|Penguin Young Readers]], [[Borders Group|Borders]], [[Barnes & Noble]], and [[American Express]]. In line with the film's theatrical release in the United States, [[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (2005 video game)|an eponymous tie-in video game]] was released on the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[GameCube]], [[Game Boy Advance]], and [[Microsoft Windows]] platforms. The film's cast provided their voices for the game, with the sole exception of [[Johnny Depp]] who was replaced by [[James Arnold Taylor]]. The game received mostly negative reviews from critics, although [[Winifred Phillips]]'s score received some praise.{{cite web|url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2005/07/20/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''|date=July 20, 2005|last=Castro|first=Juan|website=[[IGN]]|access-date=November 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305071339/https://www.ign.com/articles/2005/07/20/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory|archive-date=March 5, 2021|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps2/926603-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/index.html|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' for PlayStation 2|website=GameRankings|access-date=January 8, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701180107/http://www.gamerankings.com/ps2/926603-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/index.html|archive-date=July 1, 2014|url-status=dead}} ===Box office=== Although it opened the same day as ''[[Wedding Crashers]]'' and within a week of ''[[Fantastic Four (2005 film)|Fantastic Four]]'', the film's primary competition for its opening weekend was considered to be the [[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince|sixth installment in the]] [[Harry Potter|''Harry Potter'' book series]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/news/muggles-vs-marzipan-1117925658/|title=Muggles vs. marzipan|last=Paskin|first=Willa|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 10, 2005|access-date=June 25, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220626135850/https://variety.com/2005/film/news/muggles-vs-marzipan-1117925658/|archive-date=June 26, 2022|url-status=live}} ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' earned $56,178,450 in its opening weekend in the United States, the fifth-highest opening-weekend gross for 2005, and remained the highest-grossing film for two weeks.{{cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/year/2005/|title=2005 Domestic Grosses|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211007164237/https://www.boxofficemojo.com/year/2005/|archive-date=October 7, 2021|url-status=live}} $2.2 million of the opening weekend gross was from 65 [[IMAX]] theaters.{{cite web|date=July 18, 2005|first=Brandon|last=Gray|title={{'}}''Charlie'',' {{'}}''Crashers''{{'}} Draw Golden Box Office Ticket|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=1849&p=.htm|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|access-date=March 11, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211126193111/https://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=1849&p=.htm|archive-date=November 26, 2021|url-status=live}} At the time of release, the film's opening earnings marked Depp's highest to date, surpassing ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl|Pirates of the Caribbean]]''{{'}}s $46,630,690 opening.{{cite web|access-date=November 22, 2021|archive-date=November 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211122180922/https://www.denverpost.com/2005/07/18/charlie-sweet-at-box-office/|date=July 18, 2005|title={{'}}''Charlie''{{'}} sweet at box office|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2005/07/18/charlie-sweet-at-box-office/|url-status=live|via=[[The Denver Post]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]}} ''Charlie'' also set a record for the best-performing opening in July for a PG-rated film.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2005/more/news/box-office-confection-perfection-1117926093/|title=Box office confection perfection|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 17, 2005|access-date=June 30, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220630043633/https://variety.com/2005/more/news/box-office-confection-perfection-1117926093/|archive-date=June 30, 2022|url-status=live}} According to studio exit polling conducted during its opening weekend, 54 percent of the film's audience was under the age of 18 and the majority was female. [[File:ExpoSYFY - Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (10756984573).jpg|thumb|right|A limited set of Wonka Bars were released as part of the film's marketing campaign.]] ''Charlie''{{'}}s debut in the United Kingdom "smashed even the most optimistic industry projections", taking in $37.3 million.{{cite news|last=Mohr|first=Ian|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/box-office/french-british-love-taste-of-chocolate-1117927095/|title=French, British love taste of {{'}}''Chocolate''{{'}}|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=August 7, 2005|access-date=June 30, 2022}} The film performed well in [[France]], [[Spain]], [[Australia]], and [[Mexico]]. Its performance in [[Germany]] was considered less than expected.{{cite news|last=McNary|first=Dave|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/news/foreign-auds-eat-up-chocolate-mad-1117928890/|title=Foreign auds eat up {{'}}''Chocolate'',' {{'}}''Mad''{{'}}|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=September 11, 2005|access-date=June 30, 2022}} By the end of its theatrical run, the film had grossed $206,459,076 in the United States and $268,509,687 in foreign countries, coming to a worldwide total of $474,968,763. The film was the 58th-highest-grossing film of all time when released. Worldwide, the film was the eighth-highest-grossing film of 2005, while it was the seventh-highest in the United States and fourth-highest in the United Kingdom.{{cite web|title=British Box Office for 2005|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/year/2005/?area=GB&grossesOption=totalGrosses|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|access-date=March 11, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220311150741/https://www.boxofficemojo.com/year/2005/?area=GB&grossesOption=totalGrosses|archive-date=March 11, 2022|url-status=live}} ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' remains the [[List of highest-grossing musical films|sixteenth-highest-grossing musical film of all time]] and Tim Burton's second-highest-grossing, behind only 2010's ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]''.{{cite web|title=Tim Burton|url=https://www.the-numbers.com/person/21830401-Tim-Burton#tab=technical&all_technical_credits=od5|website=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|language=en|access-date=January 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220106064100/https://www.the-numbers.com/person/21830401-Tim-Burton|archive-date=January 6, 2022|url-status=live}} It is also the eighth-highest-grossing film of Johnny Depp's career.{{cite web|title=Johnny Depp|url=https://www.the-numbers.com/person/580401-Johnny-Depp#tab=acting&all_acting_credits=od5|website=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|language=en|access-date=June 30, 2022}} As of 2021, ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' remains the only "hit" [[Roald Dahl]] adaptation, following the underperformances of [[Wes Anderson]]'s ''[[Fantastic Mr. Fox (film)|Fantastic Mr. Fox]]'' and [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[The BFG (2016 film)|The BFG]]''. ''[[Forbes]]'' hypothesized that the film's success could be attributed to Depp and Burton being at the height of their popularity in 2005.{{cite web|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title= Why Netflix's Big Roald Dahl Acquisition Is A Huge Risk|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2021/09/23/netflix-big-roald-dahl-deal-huge-risk-wonka-depp-chalamet/?sh=136b70b6af72|website=[[Forbes]]|language=en|date=September 23, 2021|access-date=January 6, 2022|archive-url=}} ===Home media=== ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' was released on [[VHS]] and [[DVD]] on November 8, 2005.{{cite press release|url=https://www.warnerbros.com/news/press-releases/“charlie-and-chocolate-factory”-makes-its-sweet-arrival-dvd-warner-home-video|title=''Charlie And The Chocolate Factory'' Makes Its Sweet Arrival On DVD From Warner Home Video|date=September 7, 2005|publisher=[[Warner Bros.]]|access-date=September 10, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210621045706/https://www.warnerbros.com/news/press-releases/“charlie-and-chocolate-factory”-makes-its-sweet-arrival-dvd-warner-home-video|archive-date=June 21, 2021|url-status=live}} The single-disc version of the film included only two special features: an Oompa-Loompa dance tutorial and "Becoming Oompa-Loompa", which documented [[Deep Roy]]'s experience on the production. A two-disc edition was also released which included six more behind the scenes featurettes: "Chocolate Dreams", exploring the writing and [[Tim Burton]]'s vision for the film; "Different Faces, Different Flavors", exploring the characters; "Designer Chocolate", detailing the production design and costumes; "Sweet Sounds", how [[Danny Elfman]] created the Oompa-Loompa songs; "Under the Wrapper", detailing the film's practical and digital effects; and "Attack of the Squirrels", exploring how real squirrels were utilized for Veruca Salt's demise.{{cite web|first=Joshua|last=Zyber|url=https://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/review/25158|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' (HD DVD)|website=[[DVD Talk]]|date=November 20, 2006|access-date=January 12, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220113012409/https://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/review/25158|archive-date=January 13, 2022|url-status=live}} The two-disc edition also contained several games and DVD-Rom features.{{cite web|first=John|last=Latchem|url=http://www.hive4media.com/news/html/breaking_article.cfm?article_id=7970|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051122205718/http://www.hive4media.com/news/html/breaking_article.cfm?article_id=7970|title=A {{'}}''Chocolate Factory''{{'}} for Every Home|website=[[Home Media Magazine]]|archive-date=November 22, 2005|date=September 7, 2005|access-date=September 28, 2019|url-status=live}}{{cite web|first=C.S.|last=Strowbridge|url=https://www.the-numbers.com/news/191190830-DVD-Releases-for-November-8-2005|title=DVD Releases for November 8, 2005|website=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|date=November 7, 2005|access-date=January 12, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220113012407/https://www.the-numbers.com/news/191190830-DVD-Releases-for-November-8-2005|archive-date=January 13, 2022|url-status=live}} The film's DVD sales underperformed,{{cite news|last=Hettrick|first=Scott|url=https://variety.com/2005/digital/news/spending-on-dvds-up-10-1117935319/|title=Spending on DVDs up 10%|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 29, 2005|access-date=June 30, 2022}} reaching $16 million by 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Charlie-and-the-Chocolate-Factory-(2005)#tab=video-sales|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' (2005) – Financial Information|website=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|access-date=August 31, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220306023901/https://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Charlie-and-the-Chocolate-Factory-(2005)#tab=video-sales|archive-date=March 6, 2022|url-status=live}} For the film's [[HD DVD]] release in October 2006, all the behind the scenes featurettes from the two-disc edition were included. The HD DVD release also introduced an audio commentary by Burton, a music-only audio track, a "Club Reel", and an in-movie experience titled "Television Chocolate", with trivia and interviews overlayed onto the screen during the film. A [[Blu-ray]] release followed in October 2011, followed by a 10th anniversary Blu-ray release in March 2015. Both sets featured the same bonus features as the HD DVD, although the anniversary edition included a personal retrospective by Burton and a photo book.{{cite web|url=https://www.doblu.com/2015/02/24/charlie-chocolate-factory-10th-anniversary-blu-ray-review/|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'': 10th Anniversary Blu-ray Review|date=February 24, 2015|last=Zabel|first=Christopher|website=DoBlu.com|access-date=November 19, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190320001711/https://www.doblu.com/2015/02/24/charlie-chocolate-factory-10th-anniversary-blu-ray-review/|archive-date=March 20, 2019|url-status=live}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== On [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]], 83% of 228 reviews are positive, and the average rating is 7.2/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "Closer to the source material than 1971's ''Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory'', ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' is for people who like their ''Chocolate'' visually appealing and dark."{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/charlie_and_the_chocolate_factory/|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' (2005)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|access-date=February 20, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211102212401/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/charlie_and_the_chocolate_factory/|archive-date=November 2, 2021|url-status=live}} According to [[Metacritic]], which calculated a weighted average score of 72 out of 100 from 40 critic reviews, the film received "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/charlieandthechocolatefactory|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' (2005): Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|access-date=June 11, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004160436/https://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/charlieandthechocolatefactory|archive-date=October 4, 2021|url-status=live}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://whatculture.com/film/10-acclaimed-movies-everybody-now-hates|title=10 Acclaimed Movies Everybody Now Hates|date=November 16, 2019|last=Warren|first=Kate|website=[[WhatCulture]]|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200217085157/https://whatculture.com/film/10-acclaimed-movies-everybody-now-hates|archive-date=February 17, 2020|url-status=live}} [[A. O. Scott]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' gave a positive review, writing "in spite of relapses and imperfections, a few of them serious, Mr. Burton's movie succeeds in doing what far too few films aimed primarily at children even know how to attempt anymore, which is to feed—even to glut—the youthful appetite for aesthetic surprise." Scott also praised [[Alex McDowell]]'s set design, comparing the look of the factory to something out of [[Fritz Lang]]'s ''[[Metropolis (1927 film)|Metropolis]]''.{{cite news|last=Scott|first=A. O.|author-link=A. O. Scott|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/15/movies/looking-for-the-candy-finding-a-back-story.html|title=Looking for the Candy, Finding a Back Story|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 15, 2005|access-date=September 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211109125828/https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/15/movies/looking-for-the-candy-finding-a-back-story.html|archive-date=November 9, 2021|url-status=live|url-access=registration}} [[Mick LaSalle]] from the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' found ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' Burton's "best work in years. If all the laughs come from Depp, who gives Willy the mannerisms of a classic Hollywood diva, the film's heart comes from Highmore, a gifted young performer whose performance is sincere, deep and unforced in a way that's rare in a child actor."{{cite news|last=LaSalle|first=Mick|author-link=Mick LaSalle|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/07/15/DDGPJDNDGG14.DTL&hw=chocolate+factory&sn=003&sc=272|title=Depp brings a nutty center to Willy Wonka adventure|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=July 15, 2005|access-date=July 25, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211022213216/https://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/Depp-brings-a-nutty-center-to-Willy-Wonka-2655101.php|archive-date=October 22, 2021|url-status=live}} [[Peter Travers]] wrote in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine that "Depp's deliciously demented take on Willy Wonka demands to be seen. Depp goes deeper to find the bruises on Wonka's secret heart than what Gene Wilder did. Depp and Burton may fly too high on the vapors of pure imagination, but it's hard to not get hooked on something this tasty. And how about that army of Oompa-Loompas, all played by Deep Roy, in musical numbers that appear to have been choreographed by [[Busby Berkeley]] on crack."{{cite news|last=Travers|first=Peter|author-link=Peter Travers|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/6152042/charlie_and_the_chocolate_factory|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=July 14, 2005|access-date = July 25, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080620010946/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/6152042/charlie_and_the_chocolate_factory|archive-date=June 20, 2008|url-status=dead}} Depp's performance as Willy Wonka received widespread comparisons to [[Michael Jackson]].{{cite news|last=Emerson|first=Jim|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/scanners/is-willy-wonka-wacko-jacko|title=Is Willy Wonka Wacko Jacko?|work=[[RogerEbert.com]]|date=July 18, 2005|access-date=October 11, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211205012255/https://www.rogerebert.com/scanners/is-willy-wonka-wacko-jacko|archive-date=December 5, 2021|url-status=live}} [[Roger Ebert]] was among the critics who made such comparisons, citing Depp's performance as the weak spot in an "otherwise mostly delightful" film and noting "[Willy Wonka's] reclusive lifestyle, the fetishes of wardrobe and accessories, the elaborate playground built by an adult for the child inside" as parallels between the two.{{cite news|date=July 14, 2005|last=Ebert|first=Roger|author-link=Roger Ebert|title={{'}}''Chocolate''{{'}} has creepy center|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-2005|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|access-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211108030322/https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-2005|archive-date=November 8, 2021|url-status=live}} Depp was surprised by the comparisons and stated that he did not base his performance on Jackson.{{cite web|url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2005/jul/22/depp-insists-his-wonka-wacko-wasnt-jacko|title=Depp insists his Wonka wacko wasn't Jacko|date=July 22, 2005|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|access-date=October 12, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220524082230/https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2005/jul/22/depp-insists-his-wonka-wacko-wasnt-jacko|archive-date=May 24, 2022|url-status=live}} Burton dismissed the comparisons and stated that, unlike Jackson, Depp's iteration of the character does not like children.{{cite news|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Fans+wonder+what+%60Wonka%27+update+will+bring.-a0134175619|title=Fans wonder what {{'}}''Wonka''{{'}} update will bring.|date=July 15, 2005|last=Taylor|first=Lewis|newspaper=[[The Register-Guard]]|via=[[The Free Library]]|access-date=October 12, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221012064421/https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Fans+wonder+what+%60Wonka%27+update+will+bring.-a0134175619|archive-date=October 12, 2022|url-status=live}} Ann Hornaday of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' criticized Depp's acting: "The cumulative effect isn't pretty. Nor is it kooky, funny, eccentric or even mildly interesting. Indeed, throughout his fey, simpering performance, Depp seems to be straining so hard for weirdness that the entire enterprise begins to feel like those excruciating occasions when your parents tried to be hip."{{cite news|last=Hornaday|first=Ann|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/14/AR2005071402083.html|title=Sorry, Charlie|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 15, 2005|access-date=July 25, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211020081159/https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/14/AR2005071402083.html|archive-date=October 20, 2021|url-status=live}} [[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' praised Depp's performance, writing "he maintains the paradox, the mystery, of Willy Wonka: a misanthrope who has little patience for children, who can't even utter the word 'parents' without gagging, yet who invents for those same kids the purest and most luscious candies out of the sugar dream of his imagination."{{cite magazine|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|author-link=Owen Gleiberman|url=https://ew.com/article/2012/07/31/charlie-and-chocolate-factory-4/|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=July 13, 2005|access-date=July 25, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200925205828/https://ew.com/article/2012/07/31/charlie-and-chocolate-factory-4/|archive-date=September 25, 2020|url-status=live}} Depp received a [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe nomination]] for his performance. ===Gene Wilder's reaction=== In 2004, during on-set interviews while filming, Burton called the 1971 film ''[[Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory]]'' "sappy", adding, "A lot of people are huge fans of the movie and hold it in awe. I wasn't one of them."{{cite magazine|last=Ryan|first=Amy|title={{'}}''Charlie''{{'}}{{'}}s Chocolate Wars: Sweet tooth for cash?|url=https://ew.com/article/2005/06/30/johnny_depp_vs_/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 30, 2005|language=en|access-date=December 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211212023608/https://ew.com/article/2005/06/30/johnny_depp_vs_/|archive-date=December 12, 2021|url-status=live}} Depp paid homage to [[Gene Wilder]], who portrayed Willy Wonka in the first adaptation. Depp considered Wilder's performance "brilliant but subtle". He said to have had "Big shoes [to fill], though. Gene Wilder did such an awesome job in that film in the early '70s."{{cite web|last=Wilkes|first=Neil|title=Johnny Depp to play Willy Wonka|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/movies/a13903/johnny-depp-to-play-willy-wonka/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|date=March 15, 2004|access-date=December 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211212023615/https://www.digitalspy.com/movies/a13903/johnny-depp-to-play-willy-wonka/|archive-date=December 12, 2021|url-status=live}} While Wilder was appreciative towards Depp's comments, he was uncharacteristically critical of Burton's production overall stating, "It's just some people sitting around thinking 'How can we make some more money?' Why else would you remake ''Willy Wonka''? I don't see the point of going back and doing it all over again."{{cite web|last=Ulanoff|first=Lance|title=Gene Wilder's humanity always shined through|url=https://mashable.com/article/gene-wilder-remembrance|website=[[Mashable]]|language=en|date=August 29, 2016|access-date=December 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211212023608/https://mashable.com/article/gene-wilder-remembrance|archive-date=December 12, 2021|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Henry|title='One of the truly great talents': Hollywood pays tribute to Gene Wilder|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/aug/30/hollywood-pays-tribute-gene-wilder|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=August 30, 2016|language=en|access-date=December 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211212023610/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/aug/30/hollywood-pays-tribute-gene-wilder|archive-date=December 12, 2021|url-status=live}}{{cite magazine|last=Labrecque|first=Jeff|title=Gene Wilder rips Tim Burton for {{'}}''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''{{'}}|url=https://ew.com/article/2013/06/14/gene-wilder-tim-burton-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 14, 2013|language=en|access-date=December 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211212023619/https://ew.com/article/2013/06/14/gene-wilder-tim-burton-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|archive-date=December 12, 2021|url-status=live}} The filmmakers emphasized that the 2005 production of ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' was an adaptation of the 1964 book rather than a remake of the 1971 film. Depp found Wilder's remarks "disappointing", although "I can understand where he's coming from, I guess." Wilder later praised Depp's casting, saying "If I were going to cast the movie, I would cast Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka because I think he is wonderful. Mysterious—always—and magical."{{cite news|last=Saney|first=Daniel|title=Wilder endorses Johnny Depp|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/movies/a22311/wilder-endorses-johnny-depp/|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=July 4, 2005|language=en|access-date=September 22, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211101202536/https://www.digitalspy.com/movies/a22311/wilder-endorses-johnny-depp/|archive-date=November 1, 2021|url-status=live}} In 2013, Wilder made further comments calling Burton's film an "insult". He continued, "It's probably Warner Brothers' insult, I think. I like Warner Brothers for other reasons, but to do that with Johnny Depp, who I think is a good actor and I like him. But I don't care for that director [Burton] and he's a talented man, but I don't care for him for doing stuff like he did." ===Legacy=== [[File:Willy Wonka cosplay.jpg|thumb|right|A person [[cosplay]]ing as Willy Wonka.]] In the years following its release, ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' has been described as "popular but divisive",{{cite book|last=D'Addario|first=Daniel|title=Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory|magazine=[[Life (magazine)|Life]]|location=|publisher=Time Home Entertainment|date=August 6, 2021|page=79|isbn=9781547859504|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uHk8EAAAQBAJ|archive-url=https://archive.org/details/life-willy-wonka-2021/page/78/mode/2up|archive-date=June 10, 2022|url-status=live}} "love it or hate it",{{cite news|last=Sweet|first=Kat|url=https://poptonic.com/watch/movies/willy-wonka-origin-story/|title=Here's How a Willy Wonka Origin Story Will Ruin the Original|work=Poptonic|date=October 18, 2021|access-date=July 23, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220724031940/https://poptonic.com/watch/movies/willy-wonka-origin-story/|archive-date=July 24, 2022|url-status=live}} and "everlastingly polarizing".{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Scott|url=https://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/a-contentious-johnny-depp-movie-explodes-in-popularity-on-netflix/|title=A contentious Johnny Depp movie explodes in popularity on Netflix|work=[[Gamurs|We Got This Covered]]|date=December 8, 2021|access-date=February 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208175509/https://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/a-contentious-johnny-depp-movie-explodes-in-popularity-on-netflix/|archive-date=December 8, 2021|url-status=live}} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' and ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', respectively, ranked ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' as Tim Burton's third and fourth-best film.{{cite magazine|author=EW Staff|url=https://ew.com/gallery/tim-burton-movies-graded/?slide=278473#278473|title=Tim Burton's movies, from best to worst|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=August 15, 2019|access-date=September 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211001122407/https://ew.com/gallery/tim-burton-movies-graded/?slide=278473|archive-date=October 1, 2021|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/gallery/tim-burton-films-ranked-worst-to-best-batman-edward-scissorhands-johnny-depp/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-3/|title=Tim Burton's 17 Films Ranked — From Worst to Best|last=Yee|first=Lawrence|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=September 30, 2016|access-date=September 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211001193658/https://variety.com/gallery/tim-burton-films-ranked-worst-to-best-batman-edward-scissorhands-johnny-depp/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-3/|archive-date=October 1, 2021|url-status=live}} Conversely, ''[[Time Out Group|Time Out]]'' named it the worst adaptation of a Roald Dahl book, elaborating "there's something so horribly garish about Burton's film that you can't help feeling a little queasy afterwards."{{cite news|last=Huddleston|first=Tom|url=https://www.timeout.com/london/film/all-seven-roald-dahl-movies-ranked-worst-to-best|title=All seven Roald Dahl movies ranked worst to best|work=[[Time Out Group|Time Out]]|date=July 6, 2016|access-date=September 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211001193658/https://www.timeout.com/london/film/all-seven-roald-dahl-movies-ranked-worst-to-best|archive-date=October 1, 2021|url-status=live}} Although the 1971 film adaptation is considered the more beloved version, Burton's film is regarded as more faithful to Dahl's text.{{cite news|url=https://screenrant.com/charlie-chocolate-factory-willy-wonka-2005-1971-comparison-differences/|title= ''Charlie & The Chocolate Factory'' 2005 vs. 1971: Differences Explained|last=Tyler|first=Adrienne|work=[[Screen Rant]]|date=July 15, 2022|access-date=September 17, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220716043458/https://screenrant.com/charlie-chocolate-factory-willy-wonka-2005-1971-comparison-differences/|archive-date=July 16, 2022|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.looper.com/912545/the-untold-truth-of-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|title=The Untold Truth Of ''Charlie And The Chocolate Factory''|last=Gilbert|first=Emily|work=[[Static Media|Looper]]|date=June 30, 2022|access-date=September 17, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220709044412/https://www.looper.com/912545/the-untold-truth-of-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|archive-date=July 9, 2022|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thefilmagazine.com/original-vs-remake-willy-wonka-and-the-chocolate-factory-vs-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|title=Original vs Remake: ''Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory'' vs ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory''|last=Hogan|first=Katherine|work=The Film Magazine|date=December 1, 2015|access-date=September 17, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211022035120/https://www.thefilmagazine.com/original-vs-remake-willy-wonka-and-the-chocolate-factory-vs-charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory/|archive-date=October 22, 2021|url-status=live}} Guy Lodge of ''[[The Guardian]]'' claimed that the film's reputation was hurt by Depp's "off-puttingly fey, chilly spin on Wonka", even though "Burton's film handily trumps [the 1971 adaptation] for cinematic verve and vibrancy."{{cite web|last=Lodge|first=Guy|title=''Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory'' at 50: a clunky film that Roald Dahl rightly hated|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2021/jun/30/willy-wonka-chocolate-factory-roald-dahl-gene-wilder|website=[[The Guardian]]|date=June 30, 2021|language=en|access-date=December 26, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211229092207/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2021/jun/30/willy-wonka-chocolate-factory-roald-dahl-gene-wilder|archive-date=December 29, 2021|url-status=live}} [[Korey Coleman]] of ''[[Double Toasted]]'' echoed Lodge's sentiments about Depp's performance, calling it "unsettling" and "off-putting". Despite not caring for the overall film, Coleman praised Burton for applying his own vision to the story rather than imitating the 1971 adaptation.{{cite AV media|url=https://doubletoasted.com/shows/game-of-thrones-prequel-willy-wonka-prequel-and-more-the-daily-double-talk-live-145-pm-cst/|title=Game of Thrones Prequel – Willy Wonka Prequel – and More|last=Coleman|first=Korey|author-link=Korey Coleman|date=January 23, 2021|type=Podcast|website=[[Double Toasted]]|access-date=April 2, 2022|language=en|time=1:32:34}} In a series reflecting on Burton's filmography, [[Griffin Newman]] of ''[[Blank Check with Griffin & David|Blank Check]]'' praised the film, noting that it had a comic energy that was lacking in Burton's subsequent films such as ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]'' and ''[[Dark Shadows (film)|Dark Shadows]]''.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cp6zL30dJS8|title=Charlie and the Chocolate Factory with Pilot Viruet|last1=Newman|first1=Griffin|last2=Sims|first2=David|author-link1=Griffin Newman|date=March 17, 2019|type=Video|publisher=[[YouTube]]|access-date=April 2, 2022|language=en|time=29:01|quote=This movie has comic energy to it. You know, in a way that ''Alice'' doesn't, in a way that ''Dark Shadows'' can't sustain.}} ''[[Comic Book Resources]]'' noted that the film is popular among [[Generation Z|those who grew up in the 2000s]].{{cite news|url=https://www.cbr.com/why-wonka-prequel-will-work/|title=Why It's Important to Have Faith in ''Wonka''|last=Sevverlz|first=Mayoorhan|work=[[Comic Book Resources]]|date=April 26, 2022|access-date=June 5, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220615111811/https://www.cbr.com/why-wonka-prequel-will-work/|archive-date=June 15, 2022|url-status=live}} In 2020, a [[cosplay]]er emulating Depp's portrayal of Willy Wonka went viral on [[TikTok]], with ''[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]]'' dubbing him "sexy Willy Wonka".{{cite web|last=Halabian|first=Layla|title='Sexy Willy Wonka' is the TikTok meme you never asked for|url=https://www.nylon.com/entertainment/sexy-willy-wonka-tiktok-johnny-depp|website=[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]]|date=August 20, 2020|language=en|access-date=April 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220403035625/https://www.nylon.com/entertainment/sexy-willy-wonka-tiktok-johnny-depp|archive-date=April 3, 2022|url-status=live}}{{cite web|last=Rennex|first=Michelle|title=I Regret To Inform You That Gen Z Are Wildly Horny For A Johnny Depp Willy Wonka Cosplay|url=https://junkee.com/willy-wonka-tiktok-cosplay-horny/266650|website=[[Junkee]]|date=August 18, 2020|language=en|access-date=April 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220403035626/https://junkee.com/willy-wonka-tiktok-cosplay-horny/266650|archive-date=April 3, 2022|url-status=live}} During the ''[[Depp v. Heard]]'' trial, ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' was one of the most viewed films on [[Netflix]].{{cite magazine|last=Towers|first=Andrea|title=''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' spikes on Netflix amid Johnny Depp-Amber Heard trial|url=https://ew.com/movies/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-spikes-netflix-johnny-depp-trial/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|language=en|date=May 24, 2022|access-date=June 24, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220601064313/https://ew.com/movies/charlie-and-the-chocolate-factory-spikes-netflix-johnny-depp-trial/|archive-date=July 1, 2022|url-status=live}} The film was mentioned in the courtroom by Depp's attorney, who accused a psychiatrist brought in by [[Amber Heard]]'s lawyers of using Depp's film portrayals to make official diagnoses about the actor. studio = | genre = | length = | label = [[WaterTower Music|WaterTower]] | producer = | chronology = [[James Horner]] | prev_title = [[The Legend of Zorro#Music|The Legend of Zorro]] | prev_year = 2005 | next_title = [[All the King's Men (2006 film)#Soundtrack|All the King's Men]] | next_year = 2006 }} {{Music ratings |rev1 = [http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/new_world.html Filmtracks] |rev1score = {{Rating|4|5}} |rev2 = [http://moviemusicuk.us/2005/12/23/the-new-world-james-horner/ Movie Music UK] |rev2score = {{Rating|4|5}} |rev3 = [http://www.movie-wave.net/titles/new_world.html Movie Wave] |rev3score = {{Rating|4.5|5}} |rev4 = [http://www.soundtrack.net/albums/database/?id=3952 SoundtrackNet] |rev4score = {{rating|3.5|5}} }} The [[film score|musical score]] for ''The New World'' was composed by [[James Horner]]. He worked first from the script and then from edited scenes. As the film was re-edited, more changes to the score were required. Because Malick's editing was extensive and involved reordering or dropping passages or inserting sequences, much of Horner's score was not used.{{cite news|title=Terrence Malick Made An Enemy Out Of James Horner & 7 More Things We Learned About 'The New World'|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/terrence_malick_almost_directed_che_-_eight_things_we_learned_about_the_new |website=[[Indiewire]]|publisher=[[Snagfilms]]|access-date=June 25, 2016|date=July 6, 2011}} For the final version, Malick used sections of Horner's music along with the prelude to [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s ''[[Das Rheingold]]'', [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 23 (Mozart)|Piano Concerto No. 23]], and other pieces. Horner and [[Glen Ballard]] wrote and recorded the song "Listen to the Wind", sung by [[Hayley Westenra]], for the closing credits, but this too was unused.{{cite web|last1=Goldwasser|first1=Dan|title=The New World Soundtrack (2005)|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/album/the-new-world/|website=[[Soundtrack.Net]]|access-date=May 17, 2015|date=December 27, 2005}} ==Reception== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film holds an approval rating of 63% based on 192 reviews, with an average rating of 6.8/10. The site's critics consensus reads, "Despite arresting visuals and strong lead performances, ''The New World'' suffers from an unfocused narrative that will challenge viewers' attention spans over its 2 1/2 hours."{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1152954_new_world|title=The New World (2005)|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango Media|Fandango]]|access-date=February 23, 2023}} Another review aggregator [[Metacritic]] gave the film a score of 69 out of 100, based on 38 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews."{{cite web |access-date=2013-09-15 |url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/newworld |title=The New World |website=Metacritic }} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "D+" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemascore.com|title=Find CinemaScore|format=Type "New World" in the search box|publisher=[[CinemaScore]]|access-date=May 19, 2022}} [[Roger Ebert]] awarded the film a full four out of four, arguing that "what distinguishes Malick's film is how firmly he refuses to know more than he should...The events in his film, including the tragic battles between the Indians and the settlers, seem to be happening for the first time." He also lauded Malick as a "visionary". [[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' hailed the film as "a masterpiece", while others such as [[Ty Burr]] of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', [[Richard Corliss]] of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', and [[David Ansen]] of ''[[Newsweek]]'' gave positive reviews. On the other hand, [[Stephen Hunter]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' faulted the film for being "stately almost to the point of being static", while [[Joe Morgenstern]] of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' criticized it as "sluggish", "underdramatized", and "emotionally remote". While its release was timed for consideration for the awards season, it was nominated only for the [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography]] for [[Emmanuel Lubezki]] at the [[78th Academy Awards]]. In November 2009, ''[[Time Out New York]]'' ranked the film as the fourth-best of the decade, saying:
The particular power of this [[tone poem]] comes from how quietly resigned both characters are to their fates, as if they sense a guiding hand in their every action. The final passages of Malick's [[idyll]], after Pocahontas takes a fateful ocean journey, are the finest work of his career, most notably in his portrayal of the princess's death and transfiguration—a shattering five-minute sequence that never fails to move."{{cite magazine | url = http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/film/80947/the-tony-top-50-movies-of-the-decade/6.html | title = The TONY top 50 movies of the decade | magazine = [[Time Out New York]] | issue = 739 | date =November 26 – December 2, 2009 | access-date = 2009-12-02}}
In January 2010, Mick LaSalle of the ''San Francisco Chronicle'' designated it the No. 1 film of the decade.
Terence Malick's one-of-a-kind film, about the life of Pocahontas and the dawn of American history, contains some of the best filmmaking imaginable – some of it beyond imagining. I have seen it at least five times and have no idea how Malick knew, when he put it all together, that the movie would even make sense. It's difficult to write a great short poem. It's difficult to write a great long novel. But to write a great long poem that's the size of a great long novel – one that makes sense, doesn't flag and is exponentially better than the short poem or the long novel ever would have been – that's almost impossible. Malick did it. With images.Mick LaSalle, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/01/01/MVK31B78QT.DTL&type=movies "Top films of the decade"], ''San Francisco Chronicle'', 1 January 2010.
The French film magazine ''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'' ranked the film as 9th place in its list of best films of the decade 2000–2009.''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'' #652, January 2010. {{cite web |url=http://www.cahiersducinema.com/PALMARES-2000.html |title=PALMARES 2000 - Cahiers du Cinéma |access-date=2013-12-27 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104210317/http://www.cahiersducinema.com/PALMARES-2000.html |archive-date=November 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Film and television critic [[Matt Zoller Seitz]] has said it is his favorite film.''Matt Zoller Seitz introduces 'The New World{{'}}'', August 18, 2011. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQyBz9JM0Fc In ''[[The Guardian]]'', John Patterson writes that ''The New World'' "doesn't have fans, just fanatics":
This decade hasn't been up to much, movie-wise, but I am more than ever convinced that when every other scrap of celluloid from 2000-2009 has crumbled to dust, one film will remain, like some [[Ozymandias]]-like remnant of transient vanished glory in the desert. And that film is ''The New World'', Terrence Malick's American foundation myth, which arrived just as the decade reached its dismal halfway point, in January 2006. [...] ''The New World'' is a bottomless movie, almost unspeakably beautiful and formally harmonious. The movie came and went within a month, and its critical reception was characterised for the most part by bafflement, condescension, lazy ridicule and outright hostility. [...] Its siblings are to be found throughout movie history and across all national and stylistic boundaries, from the silents to [[Jean-Luc Godard]], [[James Benning (film director)|James Benning]] and [[Stan Brakhage]], or in ''[[Winstanley (film)|Winstanley]]'' and ''[[Barry Lyndon]]''. Its cultural hinterland is made up not just of other movies, but of [[Buddhism]], [[ethnography]] and [[Realism (arts)#Realism or naturalism as the depiction of ordinary, everyday subjects|naturalism]], Wagner, Mozart and the structural forms of classical music, Malick's enthusiasm for bird-watching, and a helping of [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]] and [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] [...] It is both ancient and modern, cinema at its purest and most organic, its simplest and most refined [...].{{cite news |access-date=2012-01-24 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/dec/10/the-new-world-terrence-malick |title=The New World: a misunderstood masterpiece? |newspaper=The Guardian|date=December 10, 2009 |last1=Patterson |first1=John }}
In a contribution to ''The cinema of Terrence Malick: Poetic visions of America'', film scholar [[Mark Cousins (film critic)|Mark Cousins]] writes:
By the end of ''The New World'', it seemed to me, I had experienced something like a [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s ''[[Mass in B minor]]'' or a poem by [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]]. It was about rapture and the end of rapture. It showed me seeing. It made me sensible.
In a 2016 international critics' poll conducted by the [[BBC]], ''The New World'' was voted the 39th-greatest film since 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films |title=The 21st century's 100 greatest films |publisher=BBC |date=August 23, 2016 |access-date=January 14, 2017}} ===Historical accuracy=== Most scholars agree that there was no romantic relationship between Pocahontas and Smith. She would have been 12 years old in 1608 when they were said to have first met.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03hwn09|title=Pocahontas, In Our Time - BBC Radio 4|website=BBC|access-date=2017-02-19}}{{Cite web |title=NEW WORLD LOOKS GOOD BUT TAKES LIBERTIES WITH HISTORY |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/fl-xpm-2006-01-20-0601180508-story.html |access-date=2022-09-08 |website=Sun Sentinel}} The film also depicts Pocahontas's marriage with Rolfe as being more peaceful and socially accepted than it was historically.{{Cite web |date=2012-02-09 |title=The New World: a gap-year fantasy that doesn't trip up on talking raccoons |url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/feb/09/reel-history-the-new-world |access-date=2022-09-08 |website=the Guardian |language=en}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! (Comedy or Drama) – Leading Young Actress || {{nom}} |} ==Home media== A third, 172-minute version, dubbed "The Extended Cut", was issued by New Line on [[DVD]] in October 2008.[http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/artman2/publish/movie_news/DVD-Review-The-New-World-2005-11061008.php The Hollywood News – DVD Review: The New World (2005).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014212730/http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/artman2/publish/movie_news/DVD-Review-The-New-World-2005-11061008.php |date=October 14, 2008 }} Oct 6, 2008. It contains new scenes and expansions to other scenes. The 135-minute and 172-minute cuts are widely available on DVD worldwide, with the 172-minute cut also released on [[Blu-ray]]. [[Van Morrison]] & [[The Band]])}} | title2 = [[Sail On, Sailor]] | length2 = 3:18 | extra2 = [[The Beach Boys]] | title3 = [[Let It Loose (Rolling Stones song)|Let It Loose]] | length3 = 5:18 | extra3 = [[The Rolling Stones]] | title4 = Sweet Dreams | length4 = 3:32 | extra4 = [[Roy Buchanan]] | title5 = [[One Way Out (song)|One Way Out]] | length5 = 4:57 | extra5 = [[The Allman Brothers Band]] | title6 = [[Baby Blue (Badfinger song)|Baby Blue]] | length6 = 3:36 | extra6 = [[Badfinger]] | title7 = [[I'm Shipping Up to Boston]] | length7 = 2:34 | extra7 = [[Dropkick Murphys]] | title8 = [[Nobody but Me (The Isley Brothers song)|Nobody but Me]] | length8 = 2:18 | extra8 = [[The Human Beinz]] | title9 = [[Tweedle Dee]] | length9 = 3:10 | extra9 = [[LaVern Baker]] | title10 = [[Sweet Dreams (Patsy Cline song)|Sweet Dreams (of You)]] | length10 = 2:34 | extra10 = [[Patsy Cline]] | title11 = The Departed Tango | length11 = 3:32 | extra11 = [[Howard Shore]], [[Marc Ribot]] | title12 = Beacon Hill | length12 = 2:33 | extra12 = Howard Shore, [[Sharon Isbin]] | title13 = [[Gimme Shelter]] | length13 = 3:18 | extra13 = The Rolling Stones }} ===Score=== The [[film score]] for ''The Departed'' was written by [[Howard Shore]] and performed by guitarists [[Sharon Isbin]], [[G. E. Smith]], Larry Saltzman and [[Marc Ribot]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.soundtrack.net/album/the-departed-original-score/|title=The Departed - Original Score|access-date=October 1, 2022|website=[[Soundtrack.Net]]}}</ref> The score was recorded in Shore's own studio in [[New York State]]. The album, ''The Departed: Original Score'', was released December 5, 2006 by [[New Line Records|New Line]], and produced by Jason Cienkus.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/release/10521342-Howard-Shore-The-Departed-Original-Score|title=Howard Shore – The Departed Original Score|access-date=October 1, 2022|website=[[Discogs]]}}</ref> Scorsese described the music as "a very dangerous and lethal tango" and cited the guitar-based score of ''[[Murder by Contract]]'' and the [[zither]] in ''[[The Third Man]]'' as inspiration.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cinemablend.com/new/Martin-Scorsese-Departed-Almost-Got-Sequel-Here-Why-It-Didn-t-Happen-114897.html |title=Martin Scorsese's The Departed Almost Got A Sequel, Here's Why It Didn't Happen |last1=Mcknight |first1=Brent |website=Cinema Blend |date=February 27, 2016 |access-date=March 22, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190323014040/https://www.cinemablend.com/new/Martin-Scorsese-Departed-Almost-Got-Sequel-Here-Why-It-Didn-t-Happen-114897.html|archive-date=March 23, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> ==Cancelled sequel== Although many of the key characters in the film are dead by the end, there was a script written for a sequel. This was ultimately shelved due to the expense and Scorsese's lack of interest in creating a sequel.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cinemablend.com/new/Martin-Scorsese-Departed-Almost-Got-Sequel-Here-Why-It-Didn-t-Happen-114897.html |title=Martin Scorsese's The Departed Almost Got A Sequel, Here's Why It Didn't Hierons | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The [[Film score|score]] for ''Pan's Labyrinth'' by Spanish composer [[Javier Navarrete]] was nominated for an [[Academy Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/79academyawards/nomswins.html |title=79th Annual Academy Awards Nominees and Winners |access-date=23 May 2007 |publisher=[[Academy Awards]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501001557/http://www.oscars.org/79academyawards/nomswins.html |archive-date=1 May 2007 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }} It was entirely structured around a [[lullaby]], and del Toro had the entire score included on the [[soundtrack album]], even though much of it had been cut during production. The album was released on 19 December 2006.{{cite web|url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r936979|pure_url=yes}} |title=Pan's Labyrinth soundtrack overview |access-date=4 February 2007|publisher=AllMusic.com}} Its [[cover art]] was an unused [[Drew Struzan]] promotional poster for the film. # "Long, Long Time Ago (Hace mucho, mucho tiempo)" – 2:14 # "The Labyrinth (El web|url=https://www.comingsoon.net/horror/news/708222-guillermo-del-toros-3993-details|title=Guillermo Del Toro's 3993 Details... – ComingSoon.net|date=8 November 2007|access-date=4 May The Canadian band [[Broken Social Scene]], featured prominently throughout the film, is also included on the soundtrack. ; Track listing {{Track listing | extra_column = Performer(s) | total_length = 56:46 | title1 = Stars & Sons | length1 = 5:09 | extra1 = [[Broken Social Scene]] | title2 = Evacuation | length2 = 4:12 | extra2 = The Somnambulants | title3 = Wanted | length3 = 3:27 | extra3 = [[Rhymefest]]/[[Samantha Ronson]] | title4 = Black Hearts | length4 = 3:18 | extra4 = Remy Balon | title5 = A New England | length5 = 2:14 | extra5 = [[Billy Bragg]] | title6 = The Corner | length6 = 4:20 | extra6 = [[Saigon]] | title7 = Shampoo Suicide | length7 = 4:07 | extra7 = Broken Social Scene | title8 = Na Ni Na | length8 = 5:21 | extra8 = Conjunto Céspedes | title9 = Just Begun | length9 = 4:30 | extra9 = Baby Blak/King Honey | title10 = Sometimes | length10 = 4:30 | extra10 = [[Dujeous?]] | title11 = It's Alright to Cry | length11 = 2:25 | extra11 = [[Rosey Grier]] | title12 = [[Can't You See (The Marshall Tucker Band song)|Can't You See]] | length12 = 6:03 | extra12 = [[The Marshall Tucker Band]] | title13 = Da Da Dada | length13 = 7:10 | extra13 = Broken Social Scene }} == Accolades == {{Anchor|Awards}} Many of the nominations were for Ryan Gosling, including the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]], for his performance as Dan Dunne. * [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] (Ryan Gosling) — Nominated (2006) * [[Black Reel Awards|Black Reel Award for Best Breakthrough Performance]] (Shareeka Epps) — Nominated (2007) * [[Boston Society of Film Critics Awards|Boston Society of Film Critics Award for Best New Filmmaker]] (Ryan Fleck) — Winner; Best Supporting Actress (Shareeka Epps) — Nominated (2006) * [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Actor]] (Ryan Gosling) — Nominated; Best Young Actress (Shareeka Epps) — Nominated (2007) * [[Chicago Film Critics Association Awards|Chicago Film Critics Association Award for Most Promising Performer]] (Shareeka Epps) — Nominated (2006) * [[Dallas-Fort Worth Film Critics Association Awards|Dallas-Fort Worth Film Critics Association – Russell Smith Award]] (Ryan Fleck) — Winner (2006) * [[Deauville Film Festival|Deauville Film Festival – Jury Special Prize]] Ryan Fleck — Winner; Revelations Prize (Ryan Fleck) — Winner (2006) * [[Gotham Independent Film Award for Best Feature]] (Ryan Fleck) — Winner; [[Gotham Independent Film Award for Breakthrough Actor|Breakthrough Actor]] (Shareeka Epps; Tied with [[Rinko Kikuchi]] for ''[[Babel (film)|Babel]]''); [[Gotham Independent Film Award for Breakthrough Director|Breakthrough Director]] (Ryan Fleck) — Winner (2006) * [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead]] (Shareeka Epps) — Winner; [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Male Lead]] (Ryan Gosling) — Winner; [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Director]] (Ryan Fleck) — Nominated; Best Feature (Jamie Patricof, Alex Orlovsky, Lynette Howell, Anna Boden, and Rosanne Korenberg) — Nominated; Best First Screenplay (Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck) — Nominated (2007) * [[Locarno International Film Festival]] - [[Special Jury Prize (Locarno International Film Festival)|Special Jury Prize]] (Ryan Fleck – Director, Anna Boden – Producer, Lynette Howell – Producer, Rosanne Korenberg – Producer, Alex Orlovsky – Producer, and Jamie Patricof – Producer) — Winner; Youth Jury Award – Special Mention (Ryan Fleck) — Winner; Golden Leopard (Ryan Fleck) — Nominated (2006) * [[Nantucket Film Festival|Nantucket Film Festival – Screenwriting Award]] (Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck) — Winner (2006) * [[National Board of Review|National Board of Review for Best Breakthrough Performance – Male]] (Ryan Gosling) — Winner (2006) * [[Philadelphia Film Festival|Philadelphia Film Festival for Best Director]] (Ryan Fleck) — Winner (2006) * [[San Francisco International Film Festival|San Francisco International Film Festival for Best Film]] (Ryan Fleck) — Winner (2006) * [[Seattle International Film Festival|Seattle International Film Festival – Golden Space Needle Audience Award for Best Actor]] (Ryan Gosling) — Winner (2006) * [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role]] (Ryan Gosling) — Nominated (2007) * [[Stockholm Film Festival|Stockholm Film Festival for Best Actor]] (Ryan Gosling) — Winner (2006) == Home media == ''Half Nelson'' was released on [[DVD]] on February 13, 2007, courtesy of [[ThinkFilm]] and [[Sony Pictures]].{{cite news |url=https://www.amazon.com/Half-Nelson-Ryan-Gosling/dp/B000KX0IOK |title=Half Nelson (2006) |work=Amazon.com |access-date=September 6, 2012}} Bonus features include outtakes, deleted scenes, filmmaker commentary, and a music video by [[Rhymefest]]. The film has earned $16,180,000 in rentals and $1,538,323 in DVD sales.{{cite news |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/HALFN.php |title=Half Nelson – Box Office Data, DVD Sales |work=The-Numbers.com |access-date=September 6, 2012}} It was released on [[Blu-ray]] in the United Kingdom in November 2015.[https://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=17530 Half Nelson Blu-ray]. Studio: studio = | genre = | length = 56:31 | label = Lakeshore | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Infobox album | name = [[Tropic Thunder: Original Motion Picture Score]] | type = Film | artist = [[Theodore Shapiro]] | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|2008|8|5}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 40:10 | label = [[Lakeshore Records|Lakeshore]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} ''Tropic Thunder''{{'}}s [[Film score|score]] and [[Soundtrack album|soundtrack]] were released on August 5, 2008, the week before the film's theatrical release. The score was composed by [[Theodore Shapiro]] and performed by the Hollywood Studio Symphony. William Ruhlmann of [[AllMusic]] gave the score a positive review, stating it is "...an affectionate and knowing satire of the history of Hollywood action movie music, penned by an insider."<ref name="TTScore" /> Thomas Simpson of [[Soundtrack.Net]] called it "...a mixture of fun, seriousness, rock n' roll and great scoring."<ref name="SNetScore" /> Five songs—"[[Cum On Feel the Noize]]" by [[Quiet Riot]], "[[Sympathy for the Devil]]" by [[The Rolling Stones]], "[[For What It's Worth]]" by [[Buffalo Springfield]], "[[Low (Flo Rida song)|Low]]" by [[Flo Rida]] and [[T-Pain]], and "[[Get Back (Ludacris song)|Get Back]]" by [[Ludacris]]—were not present on the soundtrack despite appearing in the film. The soundtrack features songs from [[The Temptations]], [[MC Hammer]], [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]], [[Edwin Starr]], and other artists. The single "[[Name of the Game (The Crystal Method song)|Name of the Game]]" by [[The Crystal Method]], featuring [[Styles of Beyond|Ryu]], has an exclusive [[remix]] on the soundtrack.<ref name="TTSoundtrack" /> The soundtrack debuted 20th on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s Top Soundtracks list and peaked at 39th on its Top Independent Albums list.<ref name="SoundtrackBillboard" /> James Christopher Monger of allmusic compared the music to other film's soundtracks such as ''[[Platoon (film)|Platoon]]'', ''[[Full Metal Jacket]]'', and ''[[Forrest Gump]]'' and called it "...a fun but slight listen that plays out like an old late-'70s [[K-Tel]] compilation with a few bonus cuts from the future."<ref name="AllmusicReview" /> {{Track listing | headline = Track listing<ref name="AllmusicReview" /> | extra_column = Artist | title1 = [[Name of the Game (The Crystal Method song)|Name of the Game]] | note1 = The Crystal Method's Big Ass T.T. Mix | writer1 = [[Ken Jordan (musician)|Ken Jordan]], [[Scott Kirkland]], [[Tom Morello]] | extra1 = [[The Crystal Method]] | length1 = 5:11 | title2 = [[Ball of Confusion (That's What the World Is Today)|Ball of Confusion]] | writer2 = [[Barrett Strong]], [[Norman Whitfield|Norman J. A [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] film centering on Grossman was announced in 2010.<ref name="LesFilm"/> A script has been written by [[Michael Bacall]].<ref name="LesScript"/> In 2012, Bacall said the film will explore the origin of Grossman's anger issues.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/michael-bacall-les-grossman-tom-cruise-21-jump-street-project-x-296906 | work=The archive-date =May 16, 2015}}</ref> As of 2022, Cruise and frequent collaborator [[Christopher McQuarrie]] are developing the spin-off, though it is not clear whether Grossman will be the protagonist or a supporting character.<ref>{{cite
