distributor = [[Allfilm]], Cinema 24, [[Samuel Goldwyn Films]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://estonianworld.com/culture/samuel-goldwyn-films-acquires-tangerines-rights-us/|title=Samuel Goldwyn Films acquires "Tangerines" rights in the US |newspaper=Estonian World|date=16 February 2015|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> |

Studio: studio = {{Plainlist| * Kramer & Sigman Films * [[El Deseo]] * [[Telefe|Telefe Productions]] * Corner Contenidos }} |
studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Killer Films]] * Lutzus-Brown * BSM Studio * Big Indie Pictures * Shriver Films }} |

studio = [[Tonko House|Tonko House LLC]] | released = {{Film date|2014|2|11|[[64th Berlin International Film Festival|Berlin]]|2014|3||[[New York International Children's Film Festival|NY]]}} | runtime = 18 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''The Dam Keeper''''' is a 2014 American [[animated short]] film directed by [[Robert Kondo]] and [[Daisuke Tsutsumi]]. It tells the story of Pig, an introverted youth who lives in a windmill and keeps a dark fog from engulfing his town. Although socially rejected by his peers, he is befriended by the artistic Fox. Kondo and Tsutsumi began developing the film while working as [[art directors]] on ''[[Monsters University]]'' and produced it through a co-op program at [[Pixar]]. This is Tsutsumi's second short film, after 2011's ''Sketchtravel'', and Kondo's first directorial effort. Producers Megan Bartel and Duncan Ramsay were also employees at Pixar. The film received an [[Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]]. ==Plot== Pig lives alone in a [[windmill]] on the outskirts of town. The windmill sits atop a massive wall and continually blows away a dark fog that perpetually looms outside the wall. Every day, Pig winds the windmill to keep it turning, just like his father before him. However, in town and at school, nobody likes Pig. Even though he protects the town, the other animal children make fun of him and bully him. Soon, a new student, Fox, arrives at the school carrying a sketchbook and quickly becomes rather popular. One day, she mistakingly drops the sketchbook while leaving the classroom, and Pig discovers that Fox draws mocking [[caricature]]s of classmates and teachers. Fox shows up the next day upset about losing the sketchbook, but she is quickly relieved to see that Pig has it with him. That day at school, bullies drag Pig into the restroom and harass him. Fox discovers Pig in the restroom, and consoles him and teaches him to use art as an emotional outlet for his daily hardships. The two become good friends. After school one day, Pig notices Fox surrounded by several other students looking at one of her drawings and laughing. Emboldened, Pig approaches the group. Through the crowd, Pig barely sees a mean-looking caricature of himself, with "Dirty P-" written at the top. Devastated, Pig rips the drawing out of Fox's sketchbook and runs away in tears. As evening continues, the fog draws near - Pig should be returning to his home to wind the windmill. Instead, sitting in sorrow, he puts on his gas mask and waits as the fog envelops the town while the other animals flee in terror. Eventually, Pig looks down at the drawing and discovers that he is not the only one caricatured—Fox is next to him, and the title is actually "Dirty Pals". Jolted back to his senses, Pig realizes what horrible risk the town is in. He makes his way to the windmill and manages to rid the town of the fog, losing and damaging one of the mill's propellers in the process. Pig gazes out the window of the windmill as the fog clears and the citizens begin cleaning up. Pig remembers the drawing and begins to leave. Upon opening the door, Fox is waiting for him. Pig acknowledges his misunderstanding, and she extends forgiveness to him. The two then play together inside the windmill. ==Cast== * [[Lars Mikkelsen]] as Narrator ==Production== ===Development=== [[File:Pixaranimationstudios.jpg|thumb|Directors Robert Kondo and Daisuke "Dice" Tsutsumi developed ''The Dam Keeper'' under a co-op program at Pixar.]] ''The Dam Keeper'' was produced as part of a [[co-op]] program at [[Pixar]], under which employees are allowed to develop their own films without the use of studio resources.<ref name="Mashable">{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2014/04/17/the-dam-keeper-pixar/|author=Samantha Murphy Kelly|title=How 2 Animators Independently Recreated Pixar Magic|work=[[Mashable]]|date=April 17, 2014|accessdate=February 26, 2015}}</ref> Directors [[Robert Kondo]] and [[Daisuke Tsutsumi|Daisuke "Dice" Tsutsumi]] were both [[art director]]s at Pixar. They had worked together on ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' and ''[[Monsters University]]''.<ref name="Mashable"/><ref name="NY Times">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/01/movies/awardsseason/the-dam-keeper-delivers-oscar-nomination-for-studio-alumni.html?_r=0|author=Charles Solomon|title=Embracing a Fantasy From Their Pixar Past|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 29, 2015|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> Partially facilitated by having their offices located next to one another's, a friendship quickly formed between the two of them. While Kondo's first job was at Pixar, Tsutsumi had previously been employed at [[Blue Sky Studios]]<ref name="Variety">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/awards/the-dam-keeper-filmmakers-talk-about-animated-short-oscar-nom-leaving-pixar-and-whats-next-1201429483/|author=Terry Flores|title='Dam Keeper' Filmmakers Talk About Animated Short Oscar Nom, Leaving Pixar and What's Next|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=February 10, 2015|accessdate=February 24, 2015}}</ref> and is married to a niece of famed Japanese animator [[Hayao Miyazaki]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-10-18/toy-story-3-art-director-married-to-hayao-miyazaki-niece|author=Egan Loo|title=Toy Story 3 Art Director Married to Hayao Miyazaki's Niece|work=animenewsnetwork|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=February 20, 2015}}</ref> Kondo recalls having been "fascinated by [Tsutsumi's] outside experience" and recognized at the time that his co-worker's "vision always seemed to be greater than the box [of] our responsibility."<ref name="Variety"/> In 2011, Tsutsumi released his first directorial effort - an animated short film called ''Sketchtravel''. He was aided on the film by Kondo, who worked on it as an animator.<ref name="Sketchtravel">{{cite AV media|people=Daisuke Tsutsumi; Enrico Casarosa; Robert Kondo|date=October 12, 2011|title=堤大介さんインタビュー 「スケッチトラベル」とは？|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6amCmXZJJNM|accessdate=February 20, 2015}}</ref> Kondo has described the film as having "very limited animation...like a children's book come to life."<ref name="Lightbox">{{cite AV media|people=Robert Kondo; Daisuke Tsutsumi|date=January 13, 2015|title=Lightbox - 'The Dam Keeper' directors Robert Kondo & Dice Tsutsumi (Pixar/Tonko House)|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sSfdBTFEUyU|accessdate=February 20, 2015}}</ref> Shortly after the completion of ''Sketchtravel'', Tsutsumi turned to Kondo with the idea of collaborating on a new short film.<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Lightbox"/> This was during the "heat of production" for ''Monsters University'', a time after which, as Kondo explained, most animators normally consider taking time off.<ref name="Lightbox"/> Kondo noted, "Dice wanted to take time off, but in that time, he wanted to make a film."<ref name="Lightbox"/> The two were tantalized by the potential, recognizing how much Tsutsumi had been able to achieve as a solo-director, and considering how much more they would be able to achieve together. For the following year, they developed story ideas before and after work,<ref name="Lightbox"/> sharing [[Film treatment|treatments]] with each other through [[Google Docs]]. Unable to use their Pixar offices for the task, they wrote in their home studios, cafes - anywhere that "encouraged [their] creativity" and had [[internet access]].<ref name="Mashable"/> They then got together on weekends to discuss story ideas.<ref name="Lightbox"/> ===Pre-production=== Once their duties on ''Monsters University'' were complete, Kondo and Tsutsumi took a three-month sabbatical to begin production on their project. They began without any clear intentions - the film would simply be an experiment to see "how far [they] could go".<ref name="NY Times"/> The two co-directors rented a windowless studio right across the street from Pixar.<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Crisis">{{cite AV media|people=Robert Kondo; Daisuke Tsutsumi|date=December 12, 2014|title=Making The Dam Keeper #09: Directing Featurette - Crisis|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JQtm0ZC2CBc|accessdate=February 24, 2015}}</ref> At first, they were unsure of how to approach production. "There was no real formula or no real path as to what was right", Kondo said.<ref name="Directing Featurette Origin">{{cite AV media|people=Robert Kondo; Daisuke Tsutsumi|date=December 1, 2014|title=Making The Dam Keeper #08: Directing Featurette - The Origin|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WJrNbhT-dUg|accessdate=February 21, 2015}}</ref> "We didn't know - should we be writing a script, should we be drawing moments, should we be talking about character design?"<ref name="Directing Featurette Origin"/> Not until their editor, Bradley Furnish,<ref name="Variety"/> became involved, did all of the individual elements synthesize into what the directors recognized as a potential film.<ref name="Directing Featurette Origin"/> The two directors refused to pressure themselves into striving for perfection; they just wanted to get the film done. Recognizing the process as a "learning experience", and choosing to extend this opportunity to the rest of the crew, they hired animators who were predominantly young and had just graduated from school.<ref name="Lightbox"/> "Growth was a big part of...who we selected to bring on", Kondo said.<ref name="Indiewire">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/animationscoop/robert-kondo-and-dice-tsutsumi-talk-oscar-contending-dam-keeper-short-20141201|author=Bill Desowitz|title=Immersed in Movies: Robert Kondo and Dice Tsutsumi Talk Oscar-Contending 'Dam Keeper' Short|work=[[Indiewire]]|date=December 1, 2014|accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> "We kept asking, what can you gain by working on this project?"<ref name="Indiewire"/> Rounding out the crew were fellow Pixar employees,<ref name="Mashable"/> such as Duncan Ramsay, who worked as a [[production assistant]] at the studio. Ramsay's co-workers gave him the chance to come onto ''The Dam Keeper'' in an even more distinguished position than production assistant - producer. However, Ramsay feared that balancing a project like this, on the side of his regular Pixar duties, would prove an unmanageable workload. So initially, he turned the offer down. All the same, he found himself gradually being drawn into the project, and once he committed full-scale, he convinced his friend, Megan Bartel, to come onto the film as a producer with him. Bartel characterized Ramsay as "the perfect strategist"; someone who holds an ideal mixture of warmth and intelligence.<ref name="Collegian">{{cite web|url=http://www.collegian.com/2015/02/colorado-state-alumnus-nominated-for-oscar-for-work-on-the-dam-keeper/112981/|author=McKenna Ferguson|title=Colorado State alumnus nominated for Oscar for work on "The Dam Keeper"|work=Collegian|date=February 19, 2015|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> Ramsay would hold "daily progress check-ins" throughout the film's production and found a "creative outlet" in writing the film's narration.<ref name="Collegian"/> The crew in its entirety consisted of about seventy people, though there was a "core group" of about twenty to twenty-five.<ref name="Lightbox"/> Everyone worked on a volunteer basis.<ref name="Mashable"/><ref name="Hollywood Reporter">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/pixar-alums-turn-directing-animated-760729|author=Carolyn Giardina|title=Pixar Alums Turn to Directing With Animated Short Contender 'The Dam Keeper'|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 8, 2015|accessdate=March 8, 2015}}</ref> For guidance, Kondo and Tsutsumi turned to [[Erick Oh]], one of their Pixar co-workers, who already held experience as an independent filmmaker.<ref name="Variety"/><ref name="Oh">{{cite web|url=http://www.erickoh.com/about_me.html|author=Erick Oh|title=Erick Oh - About|work=erickoh.com|accessdate=March 9, 2015}}</ref> Oh was happy to oblige. As he grew more involved with the film, he moved beyond his mere advisory role to become the film's supervising animator.<ref name="Variety"/> Although he had never worked in this position before, he found it to be like a "bridge" between animating (which he had done at Pixar) and directing (which he had done on his own films).<ref name="Oh"/><ref>{{cite AV media|people=Erick Oh|date=January 25, 2014|title=Making The Dam Keeper #01: Supervising Animator Erick Oh|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RaNwQ4cnATw&t=28|accessdate=March 7, 2015}}</ref> Official production began in early 2013.<ref name="Collegian"/> Although Kondo and Tsutsumi had planned to carry out most of the film's production within the three months that they took off from Pixar, this schedule was developed around an early version of the film that only ran for eight minutes.<ref name="Variety"/> As the film's length expanded, eventually reaching eighteen minutes, the production period stretched into a total of nine months.<ref name="Lightbox"/> "We just couldn't foresee the length of the story we wanted to tell in the beginning", Tsutsumi reflected.<ref name="Variety"/> "[But] if you look at the math, three months of eight minutes to nine months of 18 minutes is not too bad."<ref name="Variety"/> Commenting on the film's burgeoning run time, Kondo explained that eight minutes seemed insufficient to convey the kind of story that he and Tsutsumi wanted to tell - one in which a character's perception of life significantly changes. However, Kondo hopes that in the future, they will be able to make films with "just as much emotion in a shorter format."<ref name="Variety"/> ===Story development=== [[File:The Little Dutch Boy - The Dam Keeper - Cropped.jpg|thumb|left|One of the film's influences was the folktale, ''The Little Dutch Boy'' - depicted here as a statue in the [[Netherlands]].]] Primarily interested in the opportunity of collaborating, Kondo and Tsutsumi did not have any specific story in mind when they commenced.<ref name="Lightbox"/> They enjoy similar types of films, but did not immediately settle into the writing process - it took them some time to "find a way to do it together", Tsutsumi said.<ref name="Directing Featurette Origin"/> Their first idea centered on an old [[miner]] and his dog.<ref name="Directing Featurette Origin"/> This then evolved through four or five different iterations, before manifesting in its final form.<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Lightbox"/><ref name="Directing Featurette Origin"/> Drawing inspiration from ''[[The Little Dutch Boy]]'', a folktale about a young boy who saves his town by placing his finger in a [[Levee|dike]], Kondo and Tsutsumi devised a character who would hold similar responsibility, except on a day-to-day basis.<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Berkeleyside">{{cite web|url=http://www.berkeleyside.com/2015/02/17/the-dam-keeper-a-short-animated-film-by-a-berkeley-studio-nominated-for-an-oscar/|author=Tracey Taylor|title='The Dam Keeper,' a short animated film by a Berkeley studio, nominated for an Oscar|work=berkeleyside.com|date=February 17, 2015|accessdate=February 20, 2015}}</ref> [[File:The Dam Keeper - Early story idea.png|thumb|right|Concept art for one of the story iterations that Kondo and Tsutsumi considered in-between their earliest idea and ''The Dam Keeper''.]] Thematically, the duo sought to craft a story that would be true to familiar ordeals - they wanted anyone to be able to relate to the story.<ref name="Berkeleyside"/> The dark fog that encroaches upon the town serves two purposes: it comments on the "contemporary reality" of pollution, while also symbolizing Pig's struggle with internal demons.<ref name="Lightbox"/> Kondo explained that both he and Tsutsumi desired to create a world that feels "impermanent", in which things "don't seem like they can last forever."<ref name="Lightbox"/> Both directors enjoy films that are "slow-paced, poetic, [and] very quiet."<ref name="Variety"/> Although they tried to capture this aesthetic in ''The Dam Keeper'', they were also concerned about the film lagging,<ref name="Variety"/> and so they worked with their editor, Bradley Furnish, to make sure that the film has a balanced pace.<ref name="Variety"/> Tsutsumi has named [[Frédéric Back]] as his prime influence as an animator. "He [Back] always had something to say. For him, figuring out what was happening in society came first, before his craft", Tsutsumi said.<ref name="Japan Times"/> Although the two directors did not seek to make a "social statement" with their film, commentary on world issues flowed naturally into their story. "[W]e tried hard to stay true to who we are", Tsutsumi said.<ref name="Japan Times"/> [W]e are very conscious of what is happening today."<ref name="Japan Times"/> Kondo has named [[Don Bluth]] as one of his influences, and both have named [[Hayao Miyazaki]] (Tsutsumi's uncle through marriage), as well as the films of [[Walt Disney]] - in particular, ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'', ''[[Dumbo]]'', and ''[[One Hundred and One Dalmatians]]''.<ref name="Japan Times"/> Many people have asked Kondo if Pig was based on him, and if Fox was based on Tsutsumi. However, each character was actually based on both filmmakers. "I think Pig might be who we are, but Fox is who we want to be", Tsutsumi explained.<ref name="NY Times"/> He described himself and Kondo as both being "somewhat introverted".<ref name="NY Times"/> Although he supposes that they are not quite as introverted as Pig, he feels that many artists are.<ref name="NY Times"/> A [[test screening]] of the first [[story reel]] was organized for a group of Kondo and Tsutsumi's friends who had more writing experience than the two former art directors. As described by Kondo, the screening was "a disaster."<ref name="Crisis" /> The two directors recognized for themselves that the story was not working as they had wanted it to. "That was devastating", Tsutsumi said.<ref name="Crisis" /> The story was coming across as overly "heady" and did not connect emotionally.<ref name="Crisis" /> Although Kondo and Tsutsumi had wanted to finalize the story before starting production, they now had to revise it, while concurrently working on other aspects of the film. Otherwise, they would not have stayed on schedule.<ref name="Crisis" /> Looking forward, Kondo has noted that difficulties like this are unavoidable. He has said that he only hopes to be "more nimble" in dealing with them in the future.<ref name="Crisis" /> One scene was cut from the finished film. It was halfway through animation at the time and was removed since the directors thought that it "distracted from the emotional arc" of the story.<ref name="Deleted Scene">{{cite AV media|date=February 1, 2015|title=Making The Dam Keeper #11: Deleted Scene 'Late'|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eyh00yIvBtQ|accessdate=February 24, 2015}}</ref> In the scene, Pig loses track of the time, crying alone in a classroom after school. As he rushes home to the windmill, the fog nearly rolls into the town.<ref name="Deleted Scene"/> ===Animation=== As art directors at Pixar, Kondo and Tsutsumi were primarily responsible for creating concept paintings.<ref name="Berkeleyside"/> Carrying little experience with them in the actual process of animating a film,<ref name="Variety"/> the duo developed a visual style for ''The Dam Keeper'' that utilized their painting abilities.<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Variety"/><ref name="Painters">{{cite AV media|people=Robert Kondo; Daisuke Tsutsumi|date=February 11, 2015|title=Making The Dam Keeper #12 : Painters of the Dam Keeper|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Py1aKAmusCQ|accessdate=February 20, 2015}}</ref> After creating the film's animation in [[TVPaint]], a French [[digital animation]] program,<ref name="Mashable"/><ref name="Variety"/> brush-stroke effects were added to each frame in [[Photoshop]].<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Variety"/> Although Tsutsumi described this approach as "time-consuming", he felt that it "paid off in the end."<ref name="NY Times"/> Going into the project, Kondo and Tsutsumi already had similar painting styles.<ref name="Variety"/> However, they decided to learn even more from each other<ref name="Lightbox"/> and then trained their animating team to work within these styles.<ref name="NY Times"/> During their sabbatical from Pixar, the directors took their team outside to paint together and did [[still life]]s with them as well. At first, the animators made little progress. "We went from at least the two of us painting every day and producing things for the film, to none of us", Kondo remarked on the situation. Not a single frame of the film was produced during the first month. The directors later described this moment as "terrifying".<ref name="Painters"/> They began to worry that the film would never see completion. However, in a sudden turn, the animators began accomplishing more than their directors had ever anticipated of them. "Literally in a day...we went from zero to exceeding output for a week...expectations for what our production could be just exploded", Kondo said.<ref name="Painters"/> The animators learned certain techniques even faster than Kondo and Tsutsumi had. When given a task, they often returned work of a higher quality than their directors had initially asked for.<ref name="Painters"/> {{quote box|width=33%|quote="We wanted to animate light, and I think that's one of those things that's maybe unique about our film. We animated frame-by-frame the light...and we designed the light so that [it is] a huge cinematic component ...[the film] looks three-dimensional because of it."|source=Co-director Daisuke "Dice" Tsutsumi on the importance of lighting to the film's animation style.<ref name="Lightbox"/>}} About 8,000 frames were created for the film.<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Berkeleyside"/> Even though [[3D animation]] is not used in the finished version of the film, [[Autodesk Maya|Maya]] and other [[3D software]] programs were used for [[previsualization]].<ref name="Mashable"/> The directors felt that this "allowed [for] the greatest exploration of scene layout in the shortest amount of time."<ref name="Mashable"/> Tsutsumi has said that many people have mistaken the film's animation for [[CGI animation|CGI]] "with a painterly texture over it".<ref name="Lightbox"/> He actually considers this misconception to be complimentary, and he credits it to his and Kondo's painting style, which emphasizes light and "how the characters interact with [it].<ref name="Lightbox"/> On Photoshop, the animators used "[[adjustment layers]] to paint lighting on characters."<ref name="Mashable"/> This helped frames remain consistent between animators.<ref name="Mashable"/> To further aid in consistency, frames were compared in [[AfterEffects]].<ref name="Variety"/> After creating scenes for the film, animators would upload them to the [[file sharing]] service [[Box (company)|Box]], tagging the directors to indicate that the scenes "were ready for review."<ref name="Mashable"/> Kondo and Tsutsumi would then leave notes on the animators' work and do a [[Overpainting|paint-over]]. Because Box is able to save each version of a file, no one had to "worry about losing anything", Kondo explained.<ref name="Mashable"/> This helped him and Tsutsumi keep track of everything that was going on in the production. Kondo noted that without the ease of "communication, information organization and collaboration" provided by new technology, the film "would have had to have changed in scope, complexity and quality to be able to be done" on schedule."<ref name="Mashable"/> He feels that this would have been impossible to accomplish a decade earlier.<ref name="Mashable"/> ===Music=== The film's score was composed by Zach Johnston and Matteo Roberts.<ref name="Score Featurette">{{cite AV media|people=Robert Kondo; Daisuke Tsutsumi; Zach Johnston; Matteo Roberts; Minna Choi|date=May 5, 2014|title= Making The Dam Keeper #05: Score Featurette|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lIdBUCWb6Q|accessdate=February 20, 2015}}</ref> Johnston had previously collaborated with the directors on Tsutsumi's ''Sketchtravel'', as a composer and co-writer.<ref name="Score Featurette"/><ref>{{cite video|date=2011|title=Sketchtravel - ''Credits''}}</ref> The four would often converse over [[Skype]]. Kondo and Tsutsumi have no musical background, but felt that they were "in great hands" with their composers.<ref name="Score Featurette"/> They were upfront about their lack of expertise in this area. When making suggestions for the score, they would acknowledge that their ideas might not be worth using. However, Johnston and Roberts both feel that the directors made valuable musical contributions. Johnston remarked that the directors made the score "more elegant and subtle" than it would have been otherwise.<ref name="Score Featurette"/> Noting the importance of this point, Roberts said that because Pig's pain has become normalized in his life, the score should only reflect "a tinge of sadness" and not be "overly dramatic".<ref name="Score Featurette"/> Both composers greatly enjoyed their time on the film. They felt a considerable amount of freedom in crafting the score and found that there was no pressure to mimic the sound of other composers. After completing the film, Johnston joked that his and Roberts' careers would be "all down hill from here...unless Dice and Robert ask us to do another one."<ref name="Score Featurette"/> The [[Demo (music)|demo score]] was created and recorded on [[Apple (company)|Apple]]'s [[GarageBand]].<ref name="Mashable"/> Minna Choi then conducted MagicMagic Orchestra in performing the score live. They recorded at Fantasy Studios in [[Berkeley, California]]. The studio room contained a screen that would show corresponding scenes. Many of the instrumentalists found that they could not watch this without being overcome with emotion. As such, they had to avert their eyes. Tsutsumi related a moment when Choi was explaining the film's story to the orchestra, and he found her moved to tears. For his part, Kondo found it "mesmerizing" to watch Choi conduct.<ref name="Score Featurette"/> "There's something about watching someone who's incredible at their craft", he said.<ref name="Score Featurette"/> Commenting on Johnston and Roberts' score, Choi called it "tender", "sweet", and "innocent".<ref name="Score Featurette"/> ===Post-production=== When Kondo and Tsutsumi completed production on ''The Dam Keeper'', they found themselves restless at Pixar. "Of course they were great to us", Kondo said of his friends at the studio.<ref name="Variety"/> "They're our family still, but...if we didn't go back to [independent filmmaking] and challenge ourselves...in the end not only would we suffer but Pixar would suffer as well."<ref name="Variety"/> He and Tsutsumi made the difficult decision of leaving their employment behind. Tsutsumi was a new father at the time. Kondo was soon to be married.<ref name="Variety"/> Friends and family questioned them. However, the duo had grown deeply enamored with the experience of making films on their own. When they had first set out to direct ''The Dam Keeper'', they had been looking for something that could mirror the early days of Pixar. "Creating something from scratch is what 'creating' means", Tsutsumi explained.<ref name="NY Times"/> "We didn't experience that beginning and, if we stayed at Pixar, we never would."<ref name="NY Times"/> The two of them felt they had learned more in the nine months that it took to produce ''The Dam Keeper'' than in all of their previous years as art directors. They did not want this rewarding period of their lives to only last for a short while.<ref name="Variety"/> Recognizing that it would only become harder with the passing years to go out on their own, Kondo and Tsutsumi resigned from Pixar in July 2014.<ref name="Variety"/> From there, they founded their own studio, [[Tonko House]].<ref name="NY Times"/><ref name="Variety"/> Although they would eventually move locations to [[Berkeley, California]], at first Tonko House was situated within the same windowless studio that ''The Dam Keeper'' was produced in - right across the street from Pixar. Kondo and Tsutsumi invited their former boss and mentor, [[Ed Catmull]], over for a visit. He gave the duo his blessing, saying, "This is the moment you'll remember no matter what it turns into, no matter how big it becomes...that first moment, when you create something from nothing, is the best time."<ref name="NY Times"/> Tonko House derives its name from the Japanese words for pig (ton) and fox (ko).<ref name="Variety"/><ref name="Japan Times">{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2015/01/30/general/less-year-tonko-house-earns-oscar-nomination/#.VPz7RGjF98H|author=Roland Kelts|title=In less than a year, Tonko House earns an Oscar nomination|work=[[The Japan Times]]|date=January 30, 2015|accessdate=March 8, 2015}}</ref> It was not the first name that Kondo and Tsutsumi considered, but all of their other ideas were already taken. To ensure that they came up with something unused, they settled on using a "nonsensical" word, but one that would still carry an "indirect" connection to their identity and work.<ref name="Variety"/> Ko is an old-fashioned word and is not commonly used in the modern Japanese language.<ref name="Variety"/> ==Release== The film was produced without clear intentions for its release. "[W]e didn’t make ''The Dam Keeper'' to enter festivals, we just wanted to make a film. But once it was done we wanted to share it", Tsutsumi said.<ref name="Variety"/> The film was rejected by the first few festivals that it was submitted to.<ref name="Variety"/> In February 2014, it was accepted at the [[64th Berlin International Film Festival]], where it had its world premiere.<ref name="Variety"/><ref name="The Crew">{{cite AV media|date=December 25, 2014|title=Making The Dam Keeper #10: The Crew|type=video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UymxCUom0kA|accessdate=February 24, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Official Website">{{cite web|url=https://www.thedamkeeper.com/about/|title=The Dam Keeper - About|work=thedamkeeper.com|accessdate=February 25, 2015}}</ref> The US premiere followed in March, at the 17th [[New York International Children's Film Festival]].<ref name="Official Website"/> In all, over ninety festivals have screened the film.<ref name="Variety"/> The first public screening was held in December 2014 at a small cinema in Berkeley, California. At this screening, Kondo and Tsutsumi auctioned off original works of art.<ref name="Japan Times"/> With the film's Oscar nomination, it was picked up for theatrical distribution by [[Magnolia Pictures]] and [[Shorts HD]]. Premiering on January 30, 2015, in a compilation with the other 2014 Oscar-nominated, animated short films, it was screened in 350 theaters across North America, as well as several dozen in Europe and Latin America.<ref name="Japan Times"/> ===Critical reception=== Collin Souter of [[Rogerebert.com]] called ''The Dam Keeper'' "a beautiful piece of work" and speculated that it may win the Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/balder-and-dash/short-films-in-focus-the-2015-oscar-nominated-short-films|author=Collin Souter|title=Short Films in Focus: The 2015 Oscar-nominated Short Films|work=[[rogerebert.com]]|date=January 29, 2015|accessdate=February 25, 2015}}</ref> Justin Chang of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' compared the film to [[Stephen King]]'s dark novel ''[[Carrie (novel)|Carrie]]''.<ref name="Variety Chang">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/reviews/film-review-2015-oscar-nominated-short-films-animation-1201432374/|author=Justin Chang|title=Film Review: '2015 Oscar-Nominated Short Films: Animation'|work=Variety|date=February 12, 2015|accessdate=February 25, 2015}}</ref> He complimented its "moody, muted" visual style, which he thought resembled both paint and [[chalk]].<ref name="Variety Chang"/> Noting that the "ever-shifting images perfectly capture a fragile community that could easily vanish into the ether", he considered the film "emotionally harrowing."<ref name="Variety Chang"/> In an article for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Charles Solomon wrote that the film's design "suggests a canvas in motion."<ref name="NY Times"/> In a separate article for ''The New York Times'', A.O. Scott called the film "complex and rewarding."<ref name="NY Times Scott">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/30/movies/awardsseason/crisis-hotline-la-parka-joanna-and-other-short-oscar-nominees.html|author=A.O. Scott|title=And to the Point - ''Crisis Hotline'', ''La Parka'', ''Joanna'' and Other Short Oscar Nominees|work=The New York Times|date=January 29, 2015|accessdate=February 25, 2015}}</ref> He praised its commentary on both the environment and emotional struggles, while finding the character designs to be "charming, without being especially cute."<ref name="NY Times Scott"/> Carolyn Giardina of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' called the film's story "moving" and its visual design "beautiful."<ref name="Hollywood Reporter"/> Freelance critic, activist, and published author Richard Propes<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianafilmjournalists.com/contact|title=Current Members of the Indiana Film Journalists Association|work=indianafilmjournalists.com|accessdate=February 26, 2015}}</ref> wrote on his website, ''The Independent Critic'', that the film was one of the best shorts at 2014's [[Heartland Film Festival]]. Although he was unsure why it had impacted him so greatly, he declared that the film would long linger with him after seeing it. Acknowledging it as less "designed for mass consumption" than most mainstream American animation, he nonetheless wrote that it should be considered equal in entertainment value.<ref name="Independent Critic">{{cite web|url=http://theindependentcritic.com/dam_keeper|author=Richard Propes|title= "The Dam Keeper" an Official Selection at Heartland Film Festival|work=The Independent Critic|accessdate=February 26, 2015}}</ref> He gave the film an A- and praised its quiet, emotionally involving nature.<ref name="Independent Critic"/> According to the ''New York Times'', most professional animators considered ''The Dam Keeper'' the best of 2014's Oscar-nominated, animated short films. [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]] producer [[Don Hahn]] praised the film saying, "There is a sameness to much animation, so when a film like ''The Dam Keeper'' comes along, it reminds us that the boundaries of animation have barely been explored."<ref name="NY Times"/> One of ''[[How to Train Your Dragon 2]]'''s writers and directors, [[Dean DeBlois]], said that the animation style of ''The Dam Keeper'' resembles development artwork that has been given "life and poetry and movement."<ref name="NY Times"/> ===Accolades=== The film received an Oscar nomination for [[Best Animated Short Film]] at the [[87th Academy Awards]],<ref name="87th">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-30835975|title=Oscars 2015: Nominations list|work=BBC News|date=January 15, 2015 |accessdate=January 24, 2015}}</ref> but lost to Disney's ''[[Feast (2014 film)|Feast]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-oscars-2015-animated-short-film-story.html|title=Oscars 2015: 'Feast' wins for animated short|author=Noelene Clark|date=February 22, 2015|newspaper=[[LA Times]]|accessdate=February 26, 2015}}</ref> Unable to finance an Oscar campaign, Kondo and Tsutsumi formed a [[grassroots]] strategy that relied on [[social media]] platforms. They had given little consideration to the possibility of an Oscar-nomination while making the film, and Tsutsumi called the revelation "a little bit overwhelming."<ref name="Variety"/> It wasn't a part of Tonko House's plan", he said.<ref name="Variety"/> To them, the true significance of the honor is that it shows their place within the animation community.<ref name="Variety"/> {| class="wikitable" |+Awards !Award !Category !Recipient !Result !Ref(s) |- |[[87th Academy Awards]] |[[Best Animated Short Film]] |The Dam Keeper |{{Nominated}} |<ref name="87th" /> |- |[[San Francisco International Film Festival]] |Golden Gate Award | |{{Won}} |<ref name="Independent Critic" /> |- |[[New York International Children's Film Festival]] |Kids Audience Award | |{{Won}} |<ref name="Independent Critic" /> |- |[[Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF Kids]] |Young People's Jury Award | |{{Won}} |<ref name="Independent Critic" /> |- |Spark Animation Conference, Film Festival and Job Fair |Best Animated Short | |{{Won}} |<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/events/dam-keeper-wins-best-animated-short-at-spark/|title='Dam Keeper' Wins Best Animated Short at Spark|author=Mercedes Milligan|date=October 28, 2014|work=[[Animation (magazine)|Animation Magazine]]|accessdate=February 26, 2015}}</ref> |- |[[San Diego International Film Festival|San Diego Film Festival]] |Best Animated Film |The Dam Keeper |{{Won}} |<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/San-Diego-Film-Festival-Sets-2014-Winners-20141003|title=San Diego Film Festival Sets 2014 Winners|last=Desk|first=Movies News|access-date=April 23, 2018|language=en}}</ref> |} ==Other projects== ===Graphic novels=== [[First Second Books]] announced a collaboration with Tonko House to publish a trilogy of graphic novels that would expand Pig and Fox's adventures 5 years after the events of the short.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beck|first1=Jerry|title=First Second To Release Two Graphic Novels based on "The Dam Keeper"|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/animationscoop/first-second-to-release-two-graphic-novels-based-on-the-dam-keeper-20150312|website=Animation Scoop|publisher=Indiewire|accessdate=March 14, 2015|ref=March 12, 2015}}</ref> In the graphic novels, the poisonous fog recedes for the first time, leading Pig and Fox to explore the beyond with the unlikely help of one of Pig's bullies, Hippo. Along the way, the questions raised from the short on the whereabouts of Pig's parents and the poisonous fog engulfing the other side of the dam to begin with, will be answered. Robert Kondo, one of the directors and artists of The Dam Keeper, remarked that the continuation is "inspired by a personal anecdote of Tstusumi’s, [saying] that they’re interested in exploring how friendship evolves as [they] mature." They were "eight or ten" when "the kind of friends is different than when [they] grow up and start to learn about the world and who [they] are in the world.” The first graphic novel was scheduled to be published in 2016,<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Rivera|first1=Joshua|title=Exclusive: Gorgeous Oscar-nominated short The Dam Keeper to become gorgeous graphic novel series|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/03/11/gorgeous-oscar-nominated-short-dam-keeper-become-gorgeous-graphic-novel-series|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Entertainment Weekly Inc.|accessdate=March 14, 2015|ref=March 11, 2015}}</ref> but was delayed to September 26, 2017, while the second installment, "''The Dam Keeper: World Without Darkness'' was published on July 10, 2018 and the third and final graphic novel titled "''The Dam Keeper: Return from the Shadows''" was published on July 2, 2019. ===Feature film=== There is also a feature film sequel to the short that is in development with Kondo and Tsutsumi returning as directors.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Flores|first1=Terry|title=Oscar-Nominated 'Dam Keeper' Filmmakers Set Graphic Novel Deal, Developing Feature|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/oscar-nominated-dam-keeper-filmmakers-set-graphic-novel-deal-developing-feature-1201451570/|website=Variety|date=March 12, 2015 |publisher=Variety Media, LLC|accessdate=March 14, 2015|ref=March 12, 2015}}</ref> Produced by former [[Blue Sky Studios]] producer Kane Lee, it is meant to also expand the adventures of Pig and Fox just like the trilogy of graphic novels.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oscar-nominated short 'The Dam Keeper' inspires graphic novels (VIDEO)|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/read/article/oscar-nominated-short-the-dam-keeper-inspires-graphic-novels-video|website=Malay Mail Online|publisher=Malay Mail Online|accessdate=March 14, 2015|ref=March 13, 2015}}</ref> Originally, when the feature film was announced, it was in collaboration with [[20th Century Animation|20th Century Fox Animation]] during development. However, following [[Acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|The Walt Disney Company's acquisition with 21st Century Fox as of March 20, 2019]], the film is currently being developed independently at Tonko House, looking for other movie studios to collaborate with.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Milligan|first1=Mercedes|title= 'Dam Keeper' Studio Tommo House Unveils Big 2019 Slate|url=https://www.animationmagazine.net/features/dam-keeper-studio-tonko-house-unveils-big-2019-slate|website=Animation Magazine|publisher=Animation Magazine|accessdate=July 30, 2019|ref=March 4, 2019}}</ref> ===Television series=== Tonko House produced an animated television series based on the short titled ''Pig: The Dam Keeper Poems''. It premiered on [[Hulu]] in Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mobile.twitter.com/cartoonbrew/status/795475463795838980?p=v|title=Twitter|publisher=|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/internet-television/exclusive-dam-keeper-become-animated-series-hulu-japan-144618.html|title=EXCLUSIVE: 'The Dam Keeper' To Become An Animated Series for Hulu in Japan|date=November 6, 2016|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|3326262|The Dam Keeper}} * [http://thedamkeeper.com/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dam Keeper, The}} [[Category:2014 films]] [[Category:2014 drama films]] [[Category:2014 animated films]] [[Category:2014 short films]] [[Category:2010s animated short films]] [[Category:American drama short films]] [[Category:American animated short films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:2014 independent films]] [[Category:Environmental films]] [[Category:Films set in schools]] [[Category:Animated films about animals]] [[Category:Animated films about foxes]] [[Category:Films about bullying]] [[Category:First Second Books books]] [[Category:2010s English-language films]] [[Category:2010s American films]]

To promote this track, a music video was created using images of animals projected onto the side of the Empire State Building in New York. At the [[88th Academy Awards]], "[[Manta Ray (song)|Manta Ray]]" by [[J. Ralph]] & [[Anohni]] was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]]. Other nominees competing in this category were "[[Earned It]]" from ''[[Fifty Shades of Grey (film)|Fifty Shades of Grey]]'', "[[Til It Happens to You]]" from ''[[The Hunting Ground]],'' "[[Simple Song Number 3|Simple Song #3]]" from ''[[Youth (2015 film)|Youth]]'', and "[[Writing's on the Wall (Sam Smith song)|Writing's on the Wall]]" from ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]''. Studio: studio = Laokoon Filmgroup }} '''''Son of Saul''''' ({{lang-hu|'''Saul fia'''}}) is a 2015 Hungarian [[historical drama film]] directed by [[László Nemes]], in his feature directorial debut, and co-written by Nemes and [[Clara Royer]]. It is set in the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] during [[World War II]], and follows a day-and-a-half in the life of Saul Ausländer (played by [[Géza Röhrig]]), a Hungarian member of the ''[[Sonderkommando]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/15/movies/in-son-of-saul-laszlo-nemes-expands-the-language-of-holocaust-films.html|title=In 'Son of Saul,' Laszlo Nemes Expands the Language of Holocaust Films|work=The New York Times|date=14 December 2015|access-date=16 January 2016}}</ref> The film premiered at the [[2015 Cannes Film Festival]],<ref name="2015Cannes">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/article/61306.html |title=2015 Official Selection |access-date=16 April 2015 |work=Cannes}}</ref> where it won the [[Grand Prix (Cannes Film Festival)|Grand Prix]].<ref name="barnes">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/live/2015/may/24/cannes-2015-palme-dor-announcement |title=Cannes 2015: Jacques Audiard's Dheepan wins the Palme d'Or |author=Henry Barnes |date=24 May 2015 |access-date=24 May 2015 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> It was also shown in the Special Presentations section of the [[2015 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref name="ScreenDaily">{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/toronto-world-premieres-for-trumbo-demolition-the-program/5090990.article?blocktitle=LATEST-FILM-NEWS&contentID=40562# |title=Toronto to open with 'Demolition'; world premieres for 'Trumbo', 'The Program' |date=28 July 2015 |access-date=28 July 2015 |work=ScreenDaily}}</ref> The film won the award for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[88th Academy Awards]].<ref name="88nom">{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscar-nominations-2016-full-list-855670 |title=Oscar Nominations: The Complete List |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Ford |first=Rebecca |date=14 January 2016 |access-date=14 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="WinnerHWR">{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/2016-oscars-best-foreign-language-869714 |title=Oscars: Hungary Wins Its First Foreign-Language Honor Since Fall of Communism |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Szalai |first=Georg |date=28 February 2016 |access-date=29 February 2016}}</ref> It is the ninth Hungarian film to be nominated for the award, and the first since [[István Szabó]]'s ''[[Hanussen (1988 film)|Hanussen]]'' in 1988. It is the second Hungarian film to win the award, the first being Szabó's ''[[Mephisto (1981 film)|Mephisto]]'' in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oscar.go.com/nominees/foreign-language-film/son-of-saul|title=Son of Saul: Foreign Language Film – Nominees|work=Oscars|date=14 January 2016|access-date=29 February 2016}}</ref> It also won the [[73rd Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe]] for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/golden-globes-winners-2016-list-853010|title=Golden Globes: The Complete Winners List|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=11 January 2016|access-date=11 January 2016}}</ref> becoming the first Hungarian film to win the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/golden-globes-hungary-celebrates-first-854446|title=Golden Globes: Hungary Celebrates First-Ever Win for 'Son of Saul'|author=Nick Holdsworth|date=11 January 2016|access-date=16 January 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> ==Plot== In October 1944, Saul Ausländer works as a ''[[Sonderkommando]]'' [[Hungarian-Jewish|Jewish–Hungarian]] prisoner in [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]]. His job is to salvage valuables from the clothing of corpses, drag them from the [[gas chambers]] and scrub the gas chambers before the next group of victims arrives to be murdered. He works stoically, seemingly having been numbed by the daily attrocities. Among the dead after a gassing, Saul sees a boy who is still barely alive suffocated by a Nazi doctor who calls for an autopsy on the boy. Saul steps forth and insists on carrying the body himself to the prison doctor, [[Miklós Nyiszli]], a fellow Hungarian prisoner and a forced assistant to [[Josef Mengele]]. He asks Miklós to not cut up the boy, so he can give him a proper Jewish burial. Miklós declines, but says he can have five minutes alone with the boy tonight, before the cremation. Saul goes in search of a Rabbi to perform the funeral ritual. He goes to Rabbi Frankel in the crematorium, who dismisses Saul's concern and suggests that Saul perform the burial himself. Saul overhears ''Sonderkommando'' Abraham talk about an uprising against the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]-guards with ''[[Oberkapo]]'' Biederman ([[Urs Rechn]]). Biederman first wants to photograph the camp's horrors using a camera collected from the clothing of an earlier murdered caravan, and smuggle the [[Sonderkommando photographs|pictures]] outside to attract attention and help. Saul asks for another rabbi and Abraham tells him of "the Renegade," a Greek Rabbi who has lost his faith. Saul in return offers his assistance in their plan and is instructed to go with a prisoner (Katz) to repair a shack; he is given a piece of jewellery for use as a bribe in case he's caught. When Saul and Katz arrive at the shack, Saul pretends to fix the front door's lock, while Katz takes out a camera from inside the shack and starts to take pictures of the cremation. Saul hears the guards and hides the camera outside in a drain. The guards search the shack, only to find nothing. Saul then sneaks onto a truck for another ''Sonderkommando'' unit, heading to a nearby riverbank, where the ashes from the crematoria are dumped into the river. Saul finds the Renegade, who refuses to help him. Saul then threatens to alert the ''Oberkapo'' of the unit, Mietek, that the Renegade is a rabbi by reciting a [[List of Jewish prayers and blessings|Jewish blessing]]. When the Renegade refuses yet again Saul throws the man's shovel into the water. The rabbi jumps into the river to retrieve the shovel or drown himself. Saul, who can't swim, manages to bring the Renegade back to the riverbank and both are then taken to the SS-commandant of the unit. After an interrogation, the Renegade is executed and Saul is allowed to go back to the unit. Saul is then confronted by Mietek, who realizes that he is from another unit. To mollify Mietek, Saul gives him the piece of jewellery. Back at the concentration camp, following roll call, Saul sneaks into Miklós's office where he is caught by a group of Nazi officers. One of them pushes Saul around like a puppet and makes a mockery of [[Jewish dances]], finally forcing him out of the room. After searching in vain for the boy's body, Saul confronts Miklós, who assures him that he has hidden it from the other doctors for safety. Saul sneaks into the autopsy room and takes the body back to his own barrack in a sack. That night, Saul is summoned to clean the dinner tables by SS-commandant Moll. Biederman walks in and is ordered to write up a list of seventy names. This leads Biederman to believe that his unit will soon be killed. Biederman discloses the information to Abraham, who instructs Saul to head to the women's camp, where he will pick up a smuggled package of gunpowder from a prisoner named Ella. When Saul finds himself face to face with Ella, it is clear they know each other. She calls him by name and clasps his hand, but he withdraws. After collecting the package, Saul deliberately falls into a line of newly arrived Hungarian Jews, who are being led into the woods for execution. Saul, again, looks for a rabbi among the arrivals. A Frenchman named Braun approaches him and convinces Saul that he is a rabbi. Saul disguises Braun as a member of the ''Sonderkommando'' and sneaks him into the camp. When Saul arrives at the camp he is confronted by Abraham and realizes that during the turmoil in the woods he has lost the package. On further questioning, he says that the murdered boy is his illegitimate son, an assertion Abraham says is not true. The next morning during roll call, Miklós finds Saul and tells him that he needs a replacement body, similar to the one Saul has taken. The prisoners are then summoned into the crematorium to get back to work, where they discover that Biederman and his unit have been murdered by the SS. Abraham starts a riot with the other prisoners and they attack the SS guards, starting the rebellion. After managing to escape from the crematorium, Saul retrieves the boy's corpse and escapes to the woods with Braun and few other prisoners. When they reach a river, Saul finds a chance to bury the body, only to discover that Braun is a fraud when he can't recite the ''[[Kaddish]]''. When he hears the guards approaching, Saul tries to carry the body across the river. Unable to manage the current with the added weight, he loses his grasp on the sack and is pulled out of the river by Rabbi Frankel as the corpse floats away. When the prisoners arrive at a shed in the forest, they start to discuss a plan to join the [[Home Army|Polish resistance]]. Saul notices a young peasant boy peeking into the shed and smiles at him, the only time he is shown with a smile. The boy runs away, and makes it a short distance before an SS officer grabs and silences him as guards run past in the direction of the shed. When they have all passed, the officer releases him, and the boy runs into the woods as the sound of gunfire echoes behind him. == Cast == {{Cast listing| * [[Géza Röhrig]] as Saul Ausländer * [[Levente Molnár]] as Abraham Warszawski * [[Urs Rechn]] as ''Oberkapo'' Biederman * [[Sándor Zsótér]] as Dr. [[Miklós Nyiszli]] * Todd Charmont as Braun * Uwe Lauer as ''Oberscharführer'' Voss * [[Christian Harting]] as ''Oberscharführer'' Busch * Kamil Dobrowolski as ''Oberkapo'' Mietek * Jerzy Walczak as ''Sonderkommando'' rabbi * [[Marcin Czarnik]] as Feigenbaum * István Pion as Katz * Attila Fritz as Yankl * Amitai Kedar as Hirsch * Márton Ágh as Greek rabbi Apikoyres * Levente Orbán as a Russian prisoner * Tom Pilath as an ''Oberscharführer'' * Mihály Kormos as ''Kapo'' Schlojmem * Juli Jakab as Ella * Mendy Cahan as a ''Sonderkommando'' * Jeles András as [[Josef Mengele]] }} ==Production== ===Development=== Nemes conceived of the film from the book ''The Scrolls of Auschwitz'', a collection of testimonies by ''Sonderkommando'' members,<ref name="Nicholas Chare and Dominic Williams">{{cite web|last1=Chare|first1=Nicolas|last2=Wiliams|first2=Dominic|title=How Documents Buried by Jewish Prisoners at Auschwitz Tell the Story of Genocide|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_vault/2016/02/03/pages_from_the_scrolls_of_auschwitz_buried_by_the_sonderkommando.html|website=Slate: The Vault|date=3 February 2016|access-date=24 February 2016}}</ref> after discovering it during the production of [[Béla Tarr]]'s ''[[The Man from London]]'' in 2005 when he was working as Tarr's assistant.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="presskit">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmsdistribution.com/Handlers/HTFile.ashx?MEDIAID=28350|title=Son of Saul|format=PDF|publisher=Films Distribution|access-date=25 January 2016|archive-date=30 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130155807/http://www.filmsdistribution.com/Handlers/HTFile.ashx?MEDIAID=28350|url-status=dead}}</ref> Nemes started working on the screenplay with Royer in 2010 and completed the first draft in 2011.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="chan">{{cite news|last=Chang|first=Kee|date=17 May 2015|url=http://anthemmagazine.com/a-conversation-with-laszlo-nemes-clara-royer/|title=From the Archives: Son of Saul|work=Anthem Magazine|access-date=25 January 2016}}</ref> The writers spent several years on research, while historians such as [[Gideon Greif]], Philippe Mesnard and Zoltán Vági provided support for the film.<ref name="presskit" /><ref name="chan" /> The project struggled to find financial backers due to the film's unconventional approach and Nemes's lack of experience in directing a feature film.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="macnab">{{cite news|last=Macnab|first=Geoffrey|date=13 November 2015|url=http://www.screendaily.com/awards/laszlo-nemes-talks-hungarys-oscar-submission-son-of-saul/5096797.article|title=Laszlo Nemes talks Hungary's Oscar submission 'Son Of Saul'|work=[[Screen Daily]]|access-date=25 January 2016}}</ref> Originally intended to be a French production with a French protagonist, the film was produced entirely in Hungary.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="macnab" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Barraclough|first=Leo|date=27 May 2015|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/global/cannes-son-of-saul-epitomizes-spirit-ambition-of-hungarian-cinema-national-film-fund-chief-says-1201505037/|title=Cannes: 'Son of Saul' Epitomizes Spirit, Ambition of Hungarian Cinema, National Film Fund Chief Says|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=25 January 2016}}</ref> After potential co-production partners in France, Israel, Germany and Austria turned down the project, the €1.5 million budget was ultimately covered by the Hungarian National Film Fund, Hungarian tax credits and the [[Claims Conference]], accounting respectively for 70%, 25% and 5%.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="macnab" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Rodek|first=Hanns-Georg|date=26 May 2015|url=https://www.welt.de/kultur/kino/article141491336/Deutsche-Verleiher-meiden-meinen-Holocaust-Film.html|title=Deutsche Verleiher meiden meinen Holocaust-Film|work=[[Die Welt]]|language=de|access-date=25 January 2016}}</ref> ===Casting=== Nemes insisted on casting actors who spoke their characters' own languages.<ref name="macnab" /> New York City-based Hungarian poet [[Géza Röhrig]], who had not acted in film since the 1980s, was cast as the main character, Saul, after being considered originally for a supporting role.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="macnab" /> ===Filming=== The film was shot on [[35mm movie film|35 mm film]] in 28 days in [[Budafok]], [[Budapest]].<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="presskit" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Ács|first=Gábor|date=23 May 2015|url=http://hu.euronews.com/2015/05/23/cannes-az-egesz-vilagon-eladtak-nemes-laszlo-filmjet-a-saul-fiat/|title=A Saul fia rendezőjével a díjeső után|work=[[Euronews]]|language=hu|access-date=25 January 2016}}</ref> A 40 mm lens and the [[Academy ratio|Academy aspect ratio of 1.375:1]] were adopted to realise shallow focus and a portrait-like narrow field of vision.<ref name="egan">{{cite news|last=Egan|first=Jack|date=7 December 2015|url=http://www.btlnews.com/awards/director-laszlo-nemes-goes-inside-auschwitz-in-son-of-saul/|title=Director László Nemes Goes Inside Auschwitz in Son of Saul|work=Below the Line|access-date=25 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202055323/http://www.btlnews.com/awards/director-laszlo-nemes-goes-inside-auschwitz-in-son-of-saul/#|archive-date=2 February 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Su|first=Zhuo-Ning|date=8 October 2015|url=http://thefilmstage.com/features/son-of-saul-director-laszlo-nemes-on-capturing-a-portait-of-hell-and-the-spiritual-experience-of-cannes/|title='Son of Saul' Director László Nemes on Capturing a Portrait of Hell and the Spiritual Experience of Cannes|work=The Film Stage|access-date=25 January 2016}}</ref> Architect and liberal activist [[László Rajk Jr.|László Rajk]], who also worked on the permanent Hungarian exhibition at the [[Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum]], designed the re-creation of the crematoria.<ref name="kilday" /> ===Post-production=== The film took five months of sound design.<ref name="egan" /> Human voices in eight languages were recorded and attached to the original recording of the production.<ref name="kilday" /><ref name="egan" /> Sound designer Tamás Zányi described the sound in the film "as a sort of acoustic counterpoint to the intentionally narrowed imagery".<ref name="kilday" /> The film is composed of 85 shots.<ref name="kilday" /> ==Release== The film premiered in competition at the [[2015 Cannes Film Festival|68th Cannes Film Festival]] on 15 May 2015,<ref name="2015Cannes" /> where it won the [[Grand Prix (Cannes Film Festival)|Grand Prix]].<ref name="barnes" /> The filmmakers initially tried to premiere the film at the [[65th Berlin International Film Festival]], but after the festival offered them a spot only in the Panorama section, not in the main competition, they decided to refuse the proposal and instead aim for the Cannes competition.<ref name="macnab" /> In Hungary, the film was released on 11 June 2015 and sold more than 220,000 tickets, placing it as the highest-grossing domestic film released since the slapstick comedy ''Üvegtigris 3'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|author=Krezinger Szonja|title=A százezres nézőszám ma már inkább csak álom|url=https://issuu.com/metro_hungary/docs/20160321_hu_budapest?e=0|format=[[PDF]]|work=MTG Metro Gratis Kft.|publisher=Metropol|issn=2060-131X|page=8|date=21 March 2016|access-date=23 March 2017}}</ref> ==Reception== Upon its release at Cannes, the film was met with critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fandor.com/keyframe/daily-cannes-2015-laszlo-nemess-son-of-saul|title=Daily – Cannes 2015 – Laszlo Nemes's SON OF SAUL|first=David|last=Hudson|work=Keyframe|date=15 May 2015|access-date=6 December 2015|archive-date=10 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210215214/https://www.fandor.com/keyframe/daily-cannes-2015-laszlo-nemess-son-of-saul|url-status=dead}}</ref> On the review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 96% based on reviews from 229 critics, with an average rating of 8.90/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Grimly intense yet thoroughly rewarding, ''Son of Saul'' offers an unforgettable viewing experience – and establishes director László Nemes as a talent to watch".<ref>{{cite web |title= Son of Saul (2015) |url= https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/son_of_saul/ |website= [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |access-date= 8 October 2020 }}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 90 out of 100, based on reviews from 47 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".<ref>{{cite web |title= Son of Saul Reviews |url= https://www.metacritic.com/movie/son-of-saul |website= [[Metacritic]] |access-date= 19 January 2020 }}</ref> In his review for ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Peter Bradshaw]] rated the film five out of five stars, calling it an "astonishing debut film" and "a horror movie of extraordinary focus and courage". He ended his review writing: "Nemes's film has found a way to create a fictional drama with a gaunt, fierce kind of courage...."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/15/son-of-saul-review-an-outstanding-excoriating-look-at-evil-in-auchwitz|title=Son of Saul review: an outstanding, excoriating look at evil in Auschwitz|author=Peter Bradshaw|work=the Guardian|date=15 May 2015}}</ref> Writing for ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'', Dave Calhoun also gave the film five out of five stars.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/london/film/son-of-saul|title=Son of Saul|work=Time Out London}}</ref> ''[[Indiewire]]''{{'}}s Eric Kohn awarded the film an A− rating, calling it "a remarkable refashioning of the Holocaust drama that reignites the setting with extraordinary immediacy".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indiewire.com/article/cannes-review-terrifying-son-of-saul-is-unlike-any-other-holocaust-thriller-youve-seen-before-20150514|title=Cannes Review: Terrifying 'Son of Saul' is Unlike Any Oth – Indiewire|author=Eric Kohn|date=14 May 2015|work=Indiewire}}</ref> In his review written for ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', Boyd van Hoeij praised the cinematography and the soundwork of the film. He writes: "Shot (and shown in Cannes) on 35mm, often in sickly greens and yellows and with deep shadows, Erdely's cinematography is one of the film's major assets, but it wouldn't be half as effective without the soundwork, which plays a major role in suggesting what is happening around Saul, with audiences often forced to rely on the sound to imagine the whole, horrible picture".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/son-saul-saul-fia-cannes-795688|title='Son of Saul' ('Saul Fia'): Cannes Review|author=Boyd van Hoeij|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=14 May 2015}}</ref> Writing for ''The Film Stage'', Giovanni Marchini Camia gave the film an A rating, and called it "a towering landmark for filmic fictionalizations of the Holocaust".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thefilmstage.com/reviews/cannes-review-son-of-saul|title=[Cannes Review] Son of Saul|work=The Film Stage|date=16 May 2015}}</ref> A.A. Dowd of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the film an A− rating, and praised the movie's unique perspective: "''Son of Saul'' is the rare Holocaust drama that finds actual drama, and not just despair, in the living hell of a concentration camp". [...] "''Son of Saul'' sees humanity in effort, identity in action; it watches someone with nothing, a man reduced to a statistic, get a piece of himself back, mostly by finding some meaning in a place of meaningless evil".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.avclub.com/review/urgent-son-saul-holocaust-drama-no-other-229928|title=The urgent Son Of Saul is a Holocaust drama like no other|author=A.A. Dowd|date=17 December 2015|work= [[The A.V. Club]] }}</ref> [[Claude Lanzmann]], director of the documentary ''[[Shoah (film)|Shoah]]'', gave the film high praise,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/the_ticket/item/son_of_saul_a_holocaust_film_through_a_different_lens|title='Son of Saul': A Holocaust film through a different lens|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|date=29 October 2015}}</ref> stating that "it's a very new film, very original, very unusual. It's a film that gives a very real sense of what it was like to be in the ''Sonderkommando''. It's not at all melodramatic. It's done with a very great modesty".<ref name="nytimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/15/movies/in-son-of-saul-laszlo-nemes-expands-the-language-of-holocaust-films.html?_r=0|title=In 'Son of Saul,' Laszlo Nemes Expands the Language of Holocaust Films|work=The New York Times|date=14 December 2015|last1=Donadio|first1=Rachel}}</ref> Philosopher [[Georges Didi-Huberman]] also praised the film, and he wrote a 25-page open letter to Nemes, which opened with "Your film, ‘Son of Saul,' is a monster. A necessary, coherent, beneficial, innocent monster".<ref name=nytimes/> Nemes was questioned about the similarities between ''Son of Saul'' and the 2001 film ''[[The Grey Zone]]'', with Nemes replying "But mine is an Anti-''Grey Zone''!"<ref name=greyzone>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/karin-badt/cannes-grand-prix-winner_b_7549248.html|title=Cannes Grand Prix Winner "Son of Saul": A Critical Review|work=The Huffington Post|date=10 June 2015}}</ref> In a 2016 [[BBC]] poll, critics voted the film the 34th greatest since 2000.<ref>{{cite It was written by Rees and [[Virgil Williams]], who based their screenplay on the 2008 novel ''[[Mudbound]]'' by [[Hillary Jordan]]. It stars [[Carey Mulligan]], [[Garrett Hedlund]], [[Jason Clarke]], [[Jason Mitchell]], [[Jonathan Banks]], [[Rob Morgan (actor)|Rob Morgan]] and [[Mary J. Blige]].<ref>[https://www.eldinamo.cl/series-y-peliculas/2020/05/15/mudbound-la-pelicula-que-representa-el-racismo-post-segunda-guerra-mundial/ «Film Mudbound».]</ref> The film depicts two [[World War II]] veterans – one white, one black – who return to rural [[Mississippi]] each to address racism and [[PTSD]] in his own way. Motion Pictures]] | runtime = 104 minutes{{cite web|url=https://www.amctheatres.com/movies/disney-s-christopher-robin-49546|title=Christopher Robin|publisher=[[AMC Theatres]]|access-date=July 10, 2018}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $65-70 million{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-mission-impossible-6-beats-christopher-robin-35m-1132282|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|title=Weekend Box Office: 'Mission: Impossible 6' Wins More Cuddles Than 'Christopher Robin' With $35M|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=August 5, 2018|access-date=August 10, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/box-office/box-office-mission-impossible-fallout-disney-christopher-robin-1202895537/|title=Box Office: 'Mission: Impossible – Fallout' Cruises Past 'Christopher Robin'|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=August 13, 2018|access-date=August 5, 2018|first=Rebecca|last=Rubin}} | gross = $197.7 million{{cite web |title=Christopher Robin |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=disneyfairytale2017.htm |website=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[IMDb]] |access-date=March 24, 2018}} }} '''''Christopher Robin''''' is a 2018 American [[live-action animated film|live-action/animated]] [[fantasy film|fantasy]] [[comedy-drama]] film directed by [[Marc Forster]] and written by [[Alex Ross Perry]], [[Tom McCarthy (director)|Tom McCarthy]], and [[Allison Schroeder]], from a story by [[Greg Brooker (screenwriter)|Greg Brooker]] and [[Mark Steven Johnson]]. The film is inspired by [[A. A. Milne]] and [[E. H. Shepard]]'s ''[[Winnie-the-Pooh]]'' children's books{{cite web|url=http://www.wdsmediafile.com/media/ChristopherRobin/writen-material/ChristopherRobin5b087f2ba1cd8.pdf|title=Disney's Christopher Robin|publisher=[[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios]]|access-date=June 11, 2018|date=May 4, 2018|archive-date=February 16, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200216020602/http://www.wdsmediafile.com/media/ChristopherRobin/writen-material/ChristopherRobin5b087f2ba1cd8.pdf|url-status=dead}} and is a live-action/[[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] follow-up of the [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]] franchise [[Winnie the Pooh (franchise)|of the same name]]. The film stars [[Ewan McGregor]] as the [[Christopher Robin|title character]], alongside [[Hayley Atwell]] as his wife Evelyn, with the voices of [[Jim Cummings]] (reprising his roles as [[Winnie the Pooh (Disney character)|Winnie the Pooh]] and [[Tigger]]) and [[Brad Garrett]] (reprising his role as [[Eeyore]]). The story follows Christopher Robin, now an adult, who has lost his sense of imagination, only to be reunited with his childhood friend Winnie the Pooh, who he must escort back to the Hundred Acre Wood. Plans of a live-action ''Winnie the Pooh'' adaptation were announced back in April 2015, and Forster was confirmed as the director in November 2016. McGregor signed on as Christopher Robin in April 2017 and [[principal photography]] began in August of that year in the [[United Kingdom]], lasting until November. ''Christopher Robin'' premiered in [[Burbank, California]] on July 30, 2018, and was
